30th December, 1925.

Dear Sir,

During the summer of 1922 the Crown, as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, acquired a vacant parcel of land in the City of North Vancouver, B.C., the taxes being adjusted to the date of the transfer. Subsequently this Department was billed for taxes on the said parcel by the Municipality for the balance of the year on the ground that the rate for taxes for the year was struck in January of 1922 and that taxes are considered as having been imposed on and from the 1st day of January in each year. The Municipality claimed that in view of these circumstances the taxes should be paid for the balance even though for the last half of the year the property was owned by the Crown. The Department gave favourable consideration to these representations and paid the taxes for the balance of the year.

We are now in receipt of a letter from the office of the City Solicitor of North Vancouver making claim for further taxes in respect of local improvements giving particulars of the same. He states that he has ascertained that both in Vancouver and Victoria, the Government has always committed the local improvements and paid the City. He states further that the Government has some special form which it desires to be completed in such cases, which form he thinks is supplied by the Department of Public Works. I am enclosing a copy of the particulars of four Local Improvement Taxes, which the Department is being asked to pay.

Would you be good enough to advise me as to whether it is the practice in your Department to continue to pay such taxes to a municipality after the property has been acquired in the name of the Crown.

Yours truly,

J.B. Hunter, Esq., B.A.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Ottawa.
OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY MINISTER
OTTAWA

5th January, 1926

From: The Acting Deputy Minister,
Department of Public Works,

To: The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, in reference to the payment of taxes for local improvements in North Vancouver, B.C. In reply I may say that it is customary for this Department to commute such local improvement taxes and I am enclosing special forms used for that purpose. I may say also that it is the practice of the Department to continue to pay for local improvements (not general taxes, however), which may be carried out by the municipality after the property is acquired by the Crown. I would draw attention to the fact, however, that there is no legal obligation on our part in this connection, the matter is wholly at the discretion of the Government.

R.C. Desrochers,
Acting Deputy Minister.
The exception from taxation of Crown Property is by virtue of section 125 of The British North America Act. The section is imperative in its terms, not permissive, and is based on the theory that property acquired and used in establishing the necessary Public Services of Canada, should not be liable to assessment. These Public Services are established and maintained at the expense of all the people of Canada; this expense is paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund made up of taxes, direct and indirect, levied on all the rate payers. Since these services are maintained at the expense of the people of Canada, and are primarily for the benefit of all the people of Canada; and secondarily for the benefit of the people of the special locality in which they are situated; it is neither reasonable nor right that the people of Canada collectively should be assessed or required to pay taxes to the particular locality, secondarily benefitted, on the value of the works and improvements required for that service.

If it be admitted that the Municipality has the right to so tax the Crown, then the greater the value of Public Works and improvements in any city, town or municipality the larger the tax; the result being that the penalty for providing the city, town or municipality with a competent Public Service increases in direct ratio with the cost of the improvements. In other words the greater the benefit conferred on the City, Town or Municipality in this regard the greater the penalty imposed in return by the City, Town or Municipality on the people of Canada.

Having always in mind that the Public Service is established and maintained at the expense of all the people of Canada, and recognizing that the requirements of the Public Service occasion much larger expenditures in Cities and Towns than in Country Districts; the inevitable result follows that the benefits inure more largely to the urban than the rural ratepayer, while the tax is uniform; what then will be the result if the right of the various Civic Municipal bodies to tax Dominion Buildings and improvements be recognized and established? This discrepancy will be largely increased at the expense of the rural population.

Take for example the case of a municipality having no Dominion Public Buildings, as compared with that of a City having expensive Public Buildings; the ratepayers of the Municipality will be taxed not only for the establishment and maintenance of the Public Service in the City; but they will also be taxed in common with all the other ratepayers of Canada, for the exclusive benefit of the City, on the full value of the Dominion Government Buildings there. A double tax on all the ratepayers of Canada with no corresponding benefit to the Municipality in question.

The illustration is of course an extreme case, but the general result will be largely discriminative against the rural population.

No one has ever disputed the right of the individual property owner to deal with his own property as he wished; thereby doing no injury to his immediate neighbors.

No. 990 - Page 1.
The proposition that a ratepayer should be restrained from an investment which may result in loss and the consequent diminution of his assessable property, or from dealing with his real estate in such a manner as may produce a like result, is a novel one and contrary to the reasonable recognition of private rights; the parallel proposition that the Crown should be prevented from, or taxed for, taking over property and improving it with a view to establishing or improving a Public Service, is equally novel and unreasonable; and the further proposition that the Municipality should in both cases, or either case, be reimbursed for the loss of taxes occasioned by the decrease of assessable valuation within the district, is equally unsound, and directly contrary to the spirit and letter of our constitution as expressed in the B.N.A. Act.

In many Cities and Towns in Canada, the Civic Authorities have adopted the expedient of assessing Crown Property under the guise of charges for water and sewerage services, fire protection, etc., and Civic by-laws have been adopted declaring in effect, that the impost is a fee for the respective services, not a tax; notwithstanding the fact that the amount is based on the assessable valuation of the Crown Property, in the City or Town.

In my opinion this is a direct violation of both the letter and spirit of section 125 of the B.N.A. Act, and as I have already pointed out an unfair discrimination against the rural population of CANADA.

By the same methods, if recognized or approved by the Crown, this doctrine may be applied to every Civic Service, maintained for the benefit of owners of property, within any City or Town; with the result that Section 125 of the B.N.A. Act will become in effect repealed by Civic by-laws.

In my opinion a tax is levied in all cases where the impost is based on the assessable value of the Crown Property instead of the commercial value of the thing supplied, and should be met in cases of water supply to Public Buildings particularly by expropriation proceedings covering the service pipes and casements, required by the Crown, the Exchequer Court being asked to assess damages therefor based on the cost of water per gallon; as established by the cost of constructing and maintaining the water works.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) T.J. Carter,
Departmental Solicitor, P.W.D.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

In case of further investigation into the charges for local improvements in connection with our property in North Vancouver (Squamish Indian Residential School) it might be advisable to ask the Public Works to have their local district resident engineer prepare a site plan showing the size and area of our property and the municipal improvements adjoining it. We would have to submit with our request the description of the parcel. (In connection with the correspondence with the Corporation of North Vancouver and concerning the completion of the forms provided by the Public Works Department, help can be secured from Mr. D. A. Hewitt, Telephone Hunter 257).

P.W. Morris will assist in determining what improvements are of a permanent nature and should be allowed.

Room 950
Hunter

Ottawa, January 12, 1926.

Dear Mr. Desrochers:

I have to acknowledge, with thanks, your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the payment of taxes for local improvements on Crown property in North Vancouver, B.C. I note that it is the practice of your Department to continue to pay for local improvements after the property is acquired by the Crown.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

R. C. Desrochers, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Public Works,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

Re:-Block 123, D. L. 271 - Your file

You will remember that there was some correspondence between us some time ago on the above matter and finally it was suggested that you might make some arrangement as to payment of local improvement charges and send me the necessary forms for completion.

There has been some delay on this matter owing to the Treasurer and the Auditor being unable to agree with your figures. Our sinking fund is based at a 5% rate and you have computed your figures at a 6% rate. It is true that the bonds bear interest at 6% but as a matter of fact our sinking fund rate as I have stated is 5%. In other words you are computing the present value of $1.00 at 4½% whereas the City officials think this should be at a 5%.

The difference, however, only amounts to $500.00 on the whole transaction and I have been successful, at the last Council meeting, in having the forms signed on your basis, so as to get this matter settled.

I have pleasure in enclosing herewith forms, marked by you "A", "B", "C" and "D" each in triplicate and duly authenticated by the proper officers.

There is one other matter, which apparently has never been settled.

The owner, Marie Chaminade only paid a portion of the 1922 taxes; the idea being, I think, that she paid the amount apportioned to the date you took over the property. This, of course, is not in accordance with our act, as used. Taxes are levied and must be paid by the person assessed.

I believe, Mr. J. W. de B. Farris has, from time to
time given the Dominion Government advice. He is recognised as one of the ablest lawyers in B.C. and he agrees with me in my interpretation of our Municipal Act.

This, of course, will not affect you but I wish to make it quite clear that the settlement we now make with regard to local improvement is not to be taken as a relinquishment by the City of its claim against Marie Chaminade for the balance of the 1922 taxes or a relinquishment of its claim against the land.

I shall be glad if you will get the local improvement matter settled as soon as possible and forward a cheque.

Again thanking you for your help in this matter,

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

CITY SOLICITOR.

Referring to my conversation with you yesterday, I append below extract from a letter from the First Lutheran Church and the Norwegian Lutheran Mission Home, Vancouver, from the Rev. Overt Skilbred, who is Pastor and Superintendent:

"A Society is being formed under the name, the "Norsemen Society of B.C." The object of this Society is to aid the immigrants from Norway to become good citizens of the adopted land.

In order to obtain this end, they must be instructed in the language and customs of the new land. It is also necessary to stimulate their spiritual life, that they must continue in the footsteps of their fathers, who have won respect and honor among all the great nations of the world.

It is the purpose of this Society to establish its headquarters in the Province of B.C., at North Vancouver. There are at present over 60 Norwegian families and between two and three hundred individual Norsemen living there. A suitable building is being planned. This will function as a home for the newcomers and other single men who have no home of their own. The building will be arranged similar to those of the Y.M.C.A. The lecture room, or reading room, will hold about 150 people. There will be lodging rooms for about 50 single men.

These are the high spots in our plan and we hope you find that our intent is strictly within the scope of the most helpful undertakings in the upbuilding of a real Canadian Community."
You will see from the above the purpose for which the property is proposed to be acquired.

Mr. Skilbred wishes us to ascertain whether the Department would sell this property for $5,000.00 and what terms could be given for payment. The Purchasers might wish to take up the land a portion at a time, or say one-third when they commence their first block of buildings, and the balance later.

We assume that the Department will allow the usual agent's commission to us of 5% on the purchase price.

Your kind consideration and early reply will be much appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

A BY-LAW

to provide for borrowing Six Thousand, Six Hundred and Eighty-three Dollars ($6,683.00) to pay for the construction of the asphalt Macadam roadway on NAHON AVENUE from the North side of Third Street to the South side of Thirteenth Street.

WHEREAS pursuant to Construction By-law number 526, passed on the 28th day of August, 1922, an Asphalt Macadam Roadway has been constructed on Nahon Avenue from the North side of Third Street to the South side of Thirteenth Street as a local improvement, under the provisions of the "Local Improvement Act;"

AND WHEREAS the total cost of the work is Six Thousand, Six Hundred and Eighty-three ($6,683.00) Dollars, of which Two Thousand and Eighty-three ($2,083.00) Dollars is the Corporation's portion of the cost and Four Thousand, Six Hundred ($4,600.00) Dollars is the Owners' portion of the cost, for which a special assessment roll has been duly made and certified;

AND WHEREAS the estimated lifetime of the work is eleven years;

AND WHEREAS it is necessary to borrow the said sum of Six Thousand, Six Hundred and Eighty-three ($6,683.00) Dollars on the credit of the Corporation and to issue Debentures therefor, payable within Ten (10) years from the date of the issue thereof, and bearing interest at the rate of Six per cent (6%) per annum, which is the amount of the debt intended to be created by this By-law;

AND WHEREAS it will be necessary to raise annually Five Hundred and Seventy Dollars and Forty-four cents ($570.44) for the payment of the debt, and Four Hundred Dollars and Ninety-eight cents ($400.98) for the payment of the interest thereon,
making in all Nine Hundred and Seventy-one Dollars and Forty-two cents ($971.42) to be raised annually for the payment of the debt and interest, of which Three Hundred and Two Dollars and Fifty-five cents ($302.55) is required to pay the Corporation's portion of the cost and interest thereon, and Six Hundred and Sixty-eight Dollars and Eighty-seven cents ($668.87) is required to pay the Owners' portion of the cost and the interest thereon;

AND WHEREAS the whole ratesable land and improvements in the said City according to the last revised assessment roll is Twelve Million, Four Hundred and Thirty-nine Thousand, Two Hundred and Eighty-five ($12,439,285.00) Dollars;

AND WHEREAS the aggregate of the debenture debt of the Municipality (except for works of local improvement and school purposes), including the loan hereby authorized, amounts to Two Million, Three Hundred and Forty-one Thousand, Three Hundred and Ninety-one ($2,341,391.00) Dollars, and the assessed value of the land and improvements within the Municipality, according to the last revised assessment roll, is Fourteen Million, Seven Hundred and Fifty-nine Thousand, Six Hundred and Fifty-five ($14,759,655.00) Dollars and the value of the water and transportation systems owned by and constructed or purchased at the expense of the Municipality as a whole, such value being determined by the cost of such systems, less such amounts as are allowed by the Auditor from time to time, for depreciation, is Eight Hundred and Thirty-four Thousand and Eight ($834,008.00) Dollars;

THEREFORE the Municipal Council of the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver enacts as follows:-

1. It shall be lawful for the Mayor and City Clerk of the City of North Vancouver for the purpose aforesaid to borrow or raise by way of loan from any person or persons, body or bodies corporate, who may be willing to advance the same upon the credit of the said Corporation, a sum of money not exceeding in the whole Six Thousand, Six Hundred and Eighty-three ($6,683.00) Dollars;
2. Debentures of said City to the amount of Six Thousand, Six Hundred and Eighty-three ($6,683.00) Dollars in the whole may be issued by the Mayor and City Clerk of the said City of North Vancouver in such sums as may be desired, and the City Clerk shall attach thereto the Corporate Seal of the said Corporation.

3. The said debentures shall all bear the same date and shall be issued within Six (6) months after the date on which this By-law is passed and may bear any date within such Six (6) months and shall be repayable within Ten (10) years after the date thereof.

4. The said debentures shall bear interest at the rate of Six (6%) per cent per annum, payable half-yearly in each and every year during the currency of the said debentures or any of them. There shall be attached to each of the said debentures, coupons signed by the Mayor of the City only, for each and every payment of interest which may become due, and such signature may be written, stamped, printed or lithographed.

5. The said debentures shall as to principal and interest be payable in the currency of the Dominion of Canada and shall be payable as to both principal and interest at the principal office of The Royal Bank of Canada in the City of North Vancouver, the City of Montreal, or the City of Toronto, Canada.

6. During ten years - the currency of the Debentures - Five Hundred and Seventy Dollars and Forty-four cents ($570.44) shall be raised annually to form a sinking fund for the payment of the debt, and Four Hundred Dollars and Ninety-eight cents ($400.98) shall be raised annually for the payment of the interest thereon, making in all Nine Hundred and Seventy-one Dollars and Forty-two cents ($971.42) to be raised annually for payment of the debt and interest as follows:- The sum of Three Hundred and Two Dollars and Fifty-five cents ($302.55) shall be raised annually for the payment of the Corporation's portion of the cost and the interest thereon, and shall be levied and raised annually by special rate sufficient therefor over and above all other rates on all the rateable property in the Municipality, at the
same time and in the same manner as other rates:

and interest thereon a special assessment set forth in the said

therefor, as therein set forth, which said special assessment,
with a sum sufficient to cover interest thereon at the rate
aforesaid, shall be payable in ten (10) equal annual instalments

and in the same manner as other rates.

7. This By-law shall be known and cited for all
purposes as "City of North Vancouver Mahon Avenue (South),
Macadamizing local Improvement Debenture By-law, 1924."

to provide for borrowing money by the issue of debentures secured by local special rates on the property fronting or abutting upon Forbes Avenue between Third Street and Fifteenth Street for the grading of said portion of Forbes Avenue.

WHEREAS upon the recommendation of the City Engineer and in the opinion of the Council of the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver it became desirable and necessary to grade Forbes Avenue to a permanent grade from the south side of Third Street to the north side of Fifteenth Street as a work of Local Improvement under Section 54 of the "Municipal Act."

AND WHEREAS notwithstanding such publication no petition has been presented to the Council against such assessment under the provisions of Section 68 of the "Municipal Act."

AND WHEREAS it has been duly ascertained and determined pursuant to the provisions of Section 54 of the "Municipal Act" and the Local Improvement General By-law Number 2, of the City of North Vancouver that the real property fronting or abutting upon the lines described as follows, that is to say:

(a) Commencing at a point on the East side of Forbes Avenue at its intersection with the south side of Third Street then northerly along the east side of Forbes Avenue Two thousand two hundred and thirty-one decimal eighty-seven (2231.87) feet more or less to the north side of Fifteenth Street being the frontage on the east side of Forbes Avenue from Third Street to Fifteenth Street producing after deducting the width of Seven hundred and twenty-three decimal fifty (723.50) feet for street and lane intersections as shown by the statement of the frontage liable for assessment as finally settled, One thousand five hundred and eight decimal thirty seven (1508.37) feet more or less of frontage assessable on the
east side of the Avenue.

(b) Commencing at a point on the west side of Forbes Avenue at its intersection with the south side of Third Street then northerly along the west side of Forbes Avenue Two Thousand and four decimal sixty-seven (2004.67) feet more or less to the north side of Fifteenth Street being the frontage on the west side of Forbes Avenue, producing after deducting the width of Nine hundred and twenty-three decimal thirty-seven (923.37) feet for street and lane intersections and exempt property as shown by the report of the City Engineer, One thousand and eighty-one decimal thirty (1081.30) feet more or less of frontage assessable on the west side of the street or a total of two thousand five hundred and eighty-nine decimal sixty-seven (2589.67) feet of assessable property on both sides of the avenue aforesaid is immediately, directly or indirectly and specially benefitted by the said improvement and is set out in the Schedule in Section 3 hereof.

AND WHEREAS the total assessed value of the said property is Thirty-six thousand one hundred and seventy ($36,170) Dollars.

AND WHEREAS the cost as estimated by the City Engineer of the said work or improvement is the sum of Four thousand eight hundred ($4,800.) Dollars of which amount the share of the Municipality of the cost of such improvements or works is One thousand eight hundred and sixty-five dollars and ninety-two cents ($1,865.92) being the cost of grading the said Avenue opposite the said street and lane intersections and exempt property, and the remaining Two thousand nine hundred and thirty-four dollars and eight cents ($2934.08) is to be defrayed by the owners of the property benefitted which last mentioned sum of Two thousand nine hundred and thirty-four dollars and eight cents ($2934.08) together with the aforesaid sum of One thousand eight hundred and sixty-five dollars and ninety-two cents ($1865.92) making in all a total of Four thousand eight hundred ($4800) Dollars is the amount of the debt created by this By-law.

AND WHEREAS it will require the sum of Two hundred and sixteen ($216.00) Dollars to be raised annually for the period of twenty years the currency of the debentures to be issued under and by virtue of this By-law to pay the interest on the said

AND WHEREAS there are Two thousand five hundred and eighty nine decimal sixty-seven (2589.67) feet of frontage of the said assessable real property on both sides of Forbes Avenue within the limits aforesaid according to the said description and set out in the said schedule immediately, directly and specially benefitted by the said improvement and work, upon which it will be required to charge an annual special rate per foot sufficient with the amounts to be provided annually by the City to pay the interest on, and create an annual sinking fund for the payment of the said principal debt, within twenty years, which said debt is created on the security of the special rate settled by this By-law and is further guaranteed by the said Corporation at large.

LOCAL IMPROVEMENT BY-LAW NO. 49.

A BY-LAW

to provide for borrowing money by the issue of debentures secured by local special rates on the property fronting or abutting upon several streets between Burrard Inlet and 23rd Street for the construction of combined main and common sewers.

WHEREAS upon the recommendation of the City Engineer and in the opinion of the Council of the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver it became desirable and necessary to construct combined main or common sewers on the following streets and avenues:

On the Esplanade from Forbes Avenue to the East side of St. George's Avenue, On 1st Street from Forbes Avenue to the east side of St. Patrick's Avenue, On 2nd Street from Forbes Avenue to a point 300' east side of St. Andrew's Avenue, On 3rd Street from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. Andrew's Avenue, and on Forbes Avenue from Burrard Inlet to 6th Street, thence along 6th Street to Forbes Avenue, thence along continuation of Forbes Avenue to 15th Street, thence along 15th Street, to Chesterfield Avenue, thence along Chesterfield Avenue to 19th Street, thence along 19th Street to Lonsdale Avenue, thence along Lonsdale Avenue to the south side of 23rd Street (Old 22nd St.) as a work of Local Improvement under Section 256 of the Municipal Clauses Act.

AND WHEREAS notice has been given of the Council's intention of undertaking this work and of making an assessment for the cost thereof on the owners of property benefitted in accordance with subsection 22 of Section 256 of the 'Municipal Clauses Act,' which said notice was duly published in the "Express" a newspaper published in the said City of North Vancouver, British Columbia, from the second day of August 1911 to the twelfth day of August 1911.

AND WHEREAS notwithstanding such publication no petition has been presented to the Council against such assessment under the provisions of sub-section 22 of Section 256 of the Municipal Clauses Act.

AND WHEREAS it has been duly ascertained and determined pursuant to the provisions of said Section 256 of the Municipal Clauses Act and the Local Improvement General By-law Number 2, of the City of North Vancouver that the real property fronting or abutting upon the lines described as follows, that is to say:
On the south side of Esplanade from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. George's Avenue, Two thousand seven hundred and twelve and five tenths feet (2712.5).

On the north side of Esplanade from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. George's Avenue, Two thousand six hundred sixty-two and fifty-eight one hundredths feet (2662.58).

On the south side of 1st Street from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. Patrick's Avenue, Four thousand four hundred and eleven and three tenths feet (4411.3).

On the north side of 1st Street from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. Patrick's Avenue, Four thousand five hundred and nineteen and forty-two one hundredths feet (4519.42).

On the south side of 2nd from Forbes Avenue to 300' east of St. Andrew's Avenue, Four thousand twenty-six feet (4026).

On the north side of 2nd from Forbes Avenue to 300' east of St. Andrew's Avenue, Four thousand one hundred and one and five tenths feet (4101.5).

On the south side of 3rd Street from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. Andrew's Avenue Three thousand nine hundred seventy-two feet (3972).

On the north side of 3rd Street from Forbes Avenue to east side of St. Andrew's Avenue, Four thousand thirty-four and nine tenths feet (4034.9).

On the east side of Forbes Avenue from Burrard Inlet to the south side of 6th Street, One thousand six hundred and thirteen and five tenths feet (1613.5).

On the south side of 6th Street from the east side of Forbes Avenue to west side of Forbes, Two hundred and thirty feet (230).

On the East side of Forbes Avenue from south side of 6th Street to north side of 15th Street, Seven hundred and seventy-four and two tenths feet (774.2).

On the west side of Forbes Avenue from south side of 6th Street to north side of 15th Street, One thousand twenty-three and eight tenths feet (2023.8).

On the south side of 15th Street from east side of Forbes to west side of Chesterfield Avenue, One thousand nine hundred and thirty-four tenths feet (1930.4).

On the north side of 15th Street from east side of Forbes to West side of Chesterfield Avenue, One thousand nine hundred fifty-five and fifty-two one hundredths feet (1955.52).

On the east side of Chesterfield Avenue from south side of 15th Street to north side of 19th Street, One thousand three hundred thirteen and four tenths feet (1313.4).

On the west side of Chesterfield Avenue from south side of 15th Street to north side of 19th Street, One thousand three hundred and fifty-five feet (1355).

On the south side of 19th from east side of Chesterfield Avenue to west side of Lonsdale Avenue, Seven hundred and one and five tenths feet (701.5).

On the north side of 19th Street from east side of Chesterfield Avenue to west side of Lonsdale Avenue, Seven hundred and eighty feet (780).
on the east side of Lonsdale Avenue from south side of 19th Street to south side of 23rd Street, One thousand three hundred seventy-four and eighty-five one hundredths feet (1374.85).

On the west side of Lonsdale Avenue from south side of 19th Street to south side of 23rd Street, One thousand three hundred sixty-five and eight tenths feet (1365.8), making a total of Forty-five thousand eighty-eight and seventeen one hundredths feet (45,088.17), producing after deducting the width of six thousand eight hundred fifty-six feet (6856) for street and lane intersections as shown by the statement of the frontage liable for assessment as finally settled, Thirty-eight thousand two hundred and thirty-two and seventeen one hundredths feet (38,232.17) more or less of frontage assessable on both sides of the streets aforesaid is immediately, directly or indirectly and specially benefitted by the said improvement and is set out in the Schedule in Section 4 hereof.

AND WHEREAS the total assessed value of the said property is Two Million seven hundred and seventy thousand, nine hundred and eighty Dollars; and the amount of the whole rateable land or improvements or real property of the City according to the last revised assessment roll is Ten million nine hundred ninety thousand three hundred and seventy-one dollars ($10,990,371.00).

AND WHEREAS the cost as estimated by the City Engineer of the said work or improvement is the sum of One hundred and thirteen thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($113,720) of which amount the share of the Municipality of the cost of such improvements or works is forty thousand Dollars ($40,000) being the cost of constructing the said sewers opposite the said street and lane intersections and exempt property which sum of Forty thousand dollars has already been provided by an issue of general debentures of the City under authority of By-Law No., and the remaining Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($73,720) is to be defrayed by the owners of the property benefitted which last mentioned sum of Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($73,720) is the amount of the debt created by this By-law.

AND WHEREAS it will require the sum of Three thousand three hundred and seventeen dollars and forty cents ($3317.40) to be raised annually for the period of twenty years the currency of the debentures
to be issued under and by virtue of this By-law to pay the interest on the said debt, and the sum of Two thousand six hundred and six dollars and eighty-two cents ($2606.82) to be raised annually during the said period for the payment of the debt to be created by this By-law, which sum of two thousand six hundred and six dollars and eighty-two cents ($2606.82) is sufficient with the estimated interest on the investment thereof to discharge the said debt when the same becomes due and payable making in all the sum of Five thousand nine hundred and twenty-four dollars and twenty-two cents ($5924.22) to be raised annually as aforesaid.

AND WHEREAS there are Thirty-eight thousand two hundred and thirty-two and seventeen one hundredths feet (38,232.17) of frontage of the said assessable real property, on both sides of the street within the limits aforesaid according to the said description and set out in the said Schedule immediately directly or indirectly and specially benefitted by the said improvement and work, upon which it will be required to charge an annual special rate per foot sufficient with the amounts to be provided annually by the City to pay the interest on, and create an annual sinking fund for the payment of the said principal debt of Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($73,720) within twenty years, which said debt is created on the security of the special rate settled by this By-law and is further guaranteed by the said Corporation at large.

AND WHEREAS it is expedient to raise the said sum of Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($73,720) by debentures of the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver to defray the expense of said work and improvement.

THEREFORE the Council of the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver enacts as follows:

(1) It shall be lawful for the Mayor of the said City and the City Clerk to raise by way of loan from any person or persons, or body or bodies corporate who may be willing to advance the same on the credit of the debentures hereinafter mentioned, any sum or sums of money not exceeding in all the sum of Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty Dollars ($73,720) for the purposes mentioned herein.

(2) It shall be lawful for the said Mayor and City Clerk to
cause any number of debentures to be made not exceeding in value in
the whole, the sum of Seventy-three thousand seven hundred and twenty
dollars ($73,720), each such debenture to be for a sum not greater
than One thousand Dollars ($1000) or the equivalent expressed in
Pounds sterling of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland at
the value of $4.86\frac{2}{3} to the pound sterling. All such debentures shall
be signed by the said Mayor and City Clerk and the City Clerk shall
affix the Corporate Seal thereto.

(3) The said debentures shall be made payable at such certain
date on or before twenty years from the date on which this By-law
takes effect at such place or places in Great Britain, United States
of America or the Dominion of Canada as may be agreed upon between
the Corporation and the holders thereof and shall bear interest at
the rate of four and one-half per centum per annum, payable half year-
ly on the first day of March and the first day of September in each
and every year, and such debentures shall have attached to them
coupons for the payment of interest, which said coupons shall bear
the signature of the said Mayor either written, stamped, printed or
lithographed thereon. And payment of principal and interest of said
debentures is hereby guaranteed by the said Corporation at large.

(4) A special rate of 0.15495 Dollars ($0.15495) per front
foot is hereby imposed on the real property set forth and described
in the following Schedule, to wit:-
According to the frontage thereof, and above all other rates and taxes which special rate shall be sufficient to produce in each year the sum of Five thousand nine hundred and twenty-four dollars and twenty-two cents ($5924.22), and shall be annually inserted in the Collector's Roll in each year for the next succeeding twenty years and shall be payable to and collected by him in the same way as other rates on the said Roll. Provided always that no rebate shall be allowed on the said special rates or other taxes to be levied under this By-law.

(5) Such special rate shall be inserted in the Collector's Roll or Rolls and shall be payable to and collected by the said Corporation in the same way as other rates in the Roll or Rolls save as hereinafter provided. The proceeds of the said debentures shall be applied in payment of the debt incurred in the construction of the said work or improvement mentioned and set out in the preamble hereof.

(6) The Council may at any time or from time to time with the consent of the holders thereof re-purchase any of the debentures issued under this By-law and all such debentures so re-purchased shall be forthwith cancelled and destroyed and no re-issue of debentures shall be made in consequence of such re-purchase.

(7) If at any time any of the owners of the said real property hereinbefore described or any part thereof desire to commute the assessment imposed by this By-law by the payment of his or their proportionate share or shares of the cost thereof as a principal sum in lieu thereof they may so commute by the payment of $1.928 Dollars ($1.928) per foot on their property on the streets aforesaid at any time during the first year after the passing of this By-law or in any other subsequent year by the payment of such sum as may be necessary to realize at the end of the currency of said debentures a sum equivalent to the balance then unpaid of the said annual special rate thereon.

(8) All moneys arising out of the said annual special rate and all moneys received in commutation thereof under the preceding section of this By-law shall be invested by the Treasurer of this Corporation from time to time as the law directs.
(9) The debentures to be issued hereunder shall be subject to consolidation under Section 265A of the Municipal Clauses Act.

(10) This By-law shall take effect on the first day of September 1911 and may be cited for all purposes as "The North Vancouver City Local Improvement Main and Common Sewer By-law 1911."

Passed by the Council on the seventh day of July, 1911.

Reconsidered and finally adopted by the Council signed by the Mayor and City Clerk, and sealed with the Corporate Seal on the thirteenth day of July A.D. 1911.

BY-LAW NO. 171

CITY OF NORTH VANCOUVER LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DEBENTURE BY-LAW

A BY-LAW to provide for borrowing $15,476 upon the debentures to pay for the construction of an underground Sanitary Sewer with private drain connections on Fourth Street from the intersection thereof with the main Sewer line to Seventh Avenue.

WHEREAS pursuant to Construction By-law No. 88, passed on the 14th day of April, 1914, an area of land covered with private drain connections has been surveyed and mapped and located from the Sewer in the lane 135 feet West of Lonsdale Avenue to the east side of Forben Avenue as a local improvement under the provisions of the Local Improvement Act.

NOW, THEREFORE the total cost of the work is $15,476, of which $8,952.06 is the cost of the Sewer and $6,523.94 is the owner's contribution, for which a Special Assessment Roll has been duly made and certified.

The estimated useful life-time of the work is thirty-two years.

AND WHEREAS it is necessary to borrow the said sum of $15,476 on the credit of the Corporation by the issue of Debentures therefor, payable within thirty years from the date of the same thereof and bearing interest at the rate of 4.5% per annum, which is the amount of the debt incurred, plus the cost of interest thereon;

AND WHEREAS it will be necessary to raise annually the amount of the payment of the debt and $1,618.19 for the payment of interest thereon, which together in all $1,255.44 is required to be raised annually for the purpose of paying interest thereon, of which $1,131.06 is required to pay the interest on the Debentures therefor and the interest thereon, and $1,255.44 is required to pay the principal and interest thereof.

NOW, THEREFORE the whole ratable property of the Municipality, as shown on the last revised Assessment Roll is $15,688,856.

NOW, THEREFORE the amount of the existing Debenture debt of the Corporation, including all local Improvement debts secured by special rates or assessments is $1,131.06.

THEREFORE the Municipal Council of the City of North Vancouver enacts as follows:

1. In pursuance of the foregoing there shall be borrowed on the credit of the Corporation the sum of Seventeen Thousand Four Hundred and Seventy-Six Dollars ($17,476), and Debentures shall be issued therefor in such amounts as shall not exceed One Hundred and Eighty-Four Dollars ($184) for each unit of assessment therefor to the payment of the Debenture.

2. The Debentures shall all bear the same date and shall mature two years from the day on which this By-law is passed and shall be payable within such two years and shall be payable on demand at any time after the time when the same are issued.

3. The Debentures shall bear Interest at the rate of 4.5% per annum, payable half yearly and so to be calculated and expressed as to Canadian currency or sterling currency, the amount of each Debenture being expressed in Canadian currency or sterling currency, the rate of exchange being the rate of £1 sterling for each $4.86 2-3/8 cents, or such other rate of exchange as may prevail at places in Canada, Great Britain or the United States of America.

4. The Mayor of the Corporation shall sign and issue the Debentures and interest Coupons, and the same shall also be signed by the Treasurer of the Corporation, and the Debentures and the Coupons may be lithographed and the Coupons may be sealed with the Seal of the Corporation. For the purpose of the thirty years, the currency of the Debenture is $133.94 shall be sufficient to form a sinking fund for the payment of the debt and $1.618.19 for the payment of the interest thereon, making a total annual liability for the payment of the debt and interest of $1,255.44.

The sum of $1131.06 shall be charged against the credit of the Corporation's portion of the Debentures and rate of exchange therefor shall be levied and rated as a special assessment therefor, over and above all other rates assessed on the entire property in the Municipality at the same time and in the same manner.

For the payment of the owner's portion of the Debentures and interest thereon, the special assessment set forth in Schedule 1 hereto attached, which said Special Assessment Roll is hereby imposed upon the lands therein mentioned, forth.

The interest thereon, which said Special Assessment with a rate of exchange of $4.86 2-3/8 cents each, and for that purpose the Debentures and interest therefor set forth in Schedule 1 hereto attached shall be levied and collected in the said special assessment roll and the amount of the interest thereof over and above all other rates assessed thereon shall be collected annually by the Collector of Taxes at the same time and in the same manner.

6. All money arising from the said special assessment and interest thereof not immediately required for the purpose hereof shall be invested as required by law.

7. This By-law contains no clause providing for the registration of any title relating to Municipal Debentures in force.

8. The amount of the loan authorized herein shall be consolidated with the amount of the loan authorized by the Local Improvement By-laws, by including the amount of each such By-law in Consolidating By-law authorizing the issue of Debentures, the amount of each loan and the issue of each Debenture, the amount of each Debenture, the amount of each Debenture, the amount of each Debenture shall take effect on the day of the final passing thereof.

Reverend and dear Sister:

Sister Theresine, the Superior General of the Sisters of Child Jesus, has asked me to write to you with reference to Block 123, District Lot 271, in the City of North Vancouver, which property was acquired by the Crown in 1922. If you refer to your letter to Commissioner Ditchburn of May 8, 1922, you will understand that the Department feels free to dispose of the property in the open market when it is no longer required by the Squamish Indian Residential School. In the correspondence with Rev. Father Guy, of Ottawa, and Very Rev. Father Welch, of New Westminster, there is no suggestion that the land be eventually returned to the Sisters.

The City Solicitor for North Vancouver communicated with the Minister of Justice, concerning the transfer of this particular block. He asked that the Department of Justice enquire if the transaction was for the express intention of evading payment of the taxes and, if so, to have the land returned to the actual owners. I assured the Department of Justice at that time that the title for Block 123 was in the Crown and when the property was no longer necessary for our educational work, it would be publicly sold and the proceeds considered as public moneys.

Dear Dr. Scott;

I take the liberty to make application on behalf of the boys of the Squamish residential school at the solicitation of their teacher, for a grant of $90.00, for grading their proposed play ground situate on that parcel of land close to the school property which your department a few years ago purchased, in order that it may not be sold for taxes.

As you know the school property proper is small, and there is no place in it big enough for the boys attending the school to use for baseball, football and other athletic endeavor. In years gone by they used to use a field on this reserve, but a good portion of that is now occupied by the combined auditorium and manual training building which is now completed, the natural result is that the boys, (especially) and the girls have not a big enough place for muscular relaxation, which is a necessity in connection with any institution of learning. The boys of their own volition with their teacher have slashed a big enough place on the Indian Department property, for them to play on, but it requires grading, the stumps, although small would have to be pulled, the ground plowed, and then scooped so as to be made level as their a small ravine to be filled, which is now partly filled with the limbs of the trees now slashed.

Recently I asked a white man who owns a team of horses and who does that work, as what it would cost, to grade it, and he said it would cost $90.00. The sisters evidently are afraid to ask for this grant since it is hardly connected with matters of study, then the boys teacher and the boys, with the desire of having a playing field tried to get one, by slashing the property but they later found out that the task was too great for them in that they could not do work, that only a team of horses with the necessary implements can do. So the asked me to make an appeal to you, to come to their assistance and I hope you will agree with me that a playing field is a necessity to the good conduct of the boys of a school of learning.
I brought this matter to the attention of our Indian Agent Mr. C.C. Perry and asked him to ask the Department to make this grant, but his reply was that while he was not opposed to the boys having a playing field, he was reluctant to make the application as he knew that the Department had been asked to sell the property in question, and he did not know of the present position of that land. I told him that before the Department sold that land the Squamish Indians should have an opportunity to also acquire it.

The real position at present is that there not a place big enough adjoining the school for the children to play on, and for $90.00 spent in grading they could have a playing field, at the same time the Department would add to the value of the land by having it cleared and graded, the boys have already done very valuable work in slashing it.

Not being so old, and still have recollections of the time when I used to enjoy to play like those boys at present attending the school, I am in sympathy with them, in their need for a playing field, and I heartily endorse their request, if you will be good enough to have some regard for my recommendation, I trust that you will grant this prayer of boys who do not know how or who to ask, but who dearly love to have a playing field, so much so, that they have spent their recreation hours, clearing this land, instead of playing at their games. Spring is here now, and summer will soon be at hand and the grading of this property can not be too soon in the opinion of the boys, of the Squamish residential school and fully endorsed by,

Very respectfully yours

Andrew Paul.

P.S. I am not asking that this be charged to Squamish funds, but from departmental funds. A.P.

Dear Dr. Scott:

In accordance with your instructions I visited the Capilano district in company with Mr. Inspector Cairns for the purpose of examining the area of land owned by the Reverend Sisters at North Vancouver and offered by them for sale to the Department as a suitable site for a proposed new boarding school. Mr. Cairns and I were accompanied by Dr. Germain, who is attached to the Boarding School, and we made an inspection of the property together. We were all of the opinion that the site would not be at all suitable for the purposes mentioned. The land is poor, gravelly, covered with stones and badly broken up. The clearing of deadfall and other thick growth would also be very expensive. After looking over the land we returned to the school where we discussed the situation with Rev. Sister Ada and Rev. Sister Aronson, the former appearing to know nothing about the condition of the land and the latter stating that the primary object in asking the Department to purchase the area was to get rid of the land and obtain, if possible, a return to them of an investment on the same of approximately $15,000.00.

These Sisters have carried this land since about 1912, paying taxes thereon, and it is our opinion that they were badly misled as to the quality and fitness of the land for their purposes at the time it was sold to them. We advised the Sisters that the best test of the value of this land would be to advertise the same for sale and see what offers they would get for it in that way.

It occurred to us whilst discussing the situation that a possible solution of the school problem at North Vancouver might be:

1. The acquisition by the Department of the present site of the Squamish Residential School with its orchard, garden and other improvements.

2. The creation of a block of land for school purposes of approximately twenty acres by adding to the existing school property the block which the Department purchased some years ago from the Sisters to relieve them from the burden of taxation and the acquisition of an additional strip of land by purchase from the Squamish Indians in the Mission Reserve No. 1 adjoining the present school site.

Were it not for the fact that the Department

We informed the Reverend Sisters that we could not recommend the purchase of their land and although they seemed somewhat disappointed they stated that they thought our observations quite fair and reasonable.

Dear Madam:

Re School Project

In furtherance of our several conversations and visits to the properties in question, and your desire for my views in writing, I herewith give you same.

Re School adjacent to Indian Reserve.

I understand the Indian Department desires to build to give more and better accommodation to the Indian children of school age, having in view the acquiring of land adjacent to the present school. Personally, I do not think that this would be advisable, for the following reasons:

1. That although the Inlet separates the City of Vancouver from North Vancouver, yet from a commercial and shipping standpoint they are one. As Vancouver advances, so will the North side advance. All foreshore from the First Narrows - both sides of Burrard Inlet - to Port Moody will be utilized before long, and come under the control of the Harbour Commissioners.

2. As regards a school of this nature, you ought to have a large area of ground for playgrounds and for general farm use and the Indian Reserve is not suitable. This site will most certainly be purchased for industrial purposes very soon.

Re Acreage at Capilano

In company with Mr. Astbury we made two trips and viewed the ground, and whilst we did not cover all of it we got a fair idea of its layout.

Whilst there are stones of various size upon it, still they are loose. The ground is of a black sandy loam nature and is sloping more or less from the North to the South. I am informed that there are about fourteen acres
in the two pieces, and this I think should be enough to place a school upon, such as the one you now have at North Vancouver.

Whilst the clearing might cost two or three hundred dollars per acre, still as you stated that you would give the land free to the Department of Indian Affairs to build a school upon, it would in my opinion be a good move for the Department to seriously consider this proposition towards taking up your offer.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I know you will not mind my taking the liberty of calling to your attention the plight of the good Sisters of the Child Jesus, at North Vancouver, B.C., in the hope that you may see fit to investigate the problems now confronting them, and ask you for them, what Government assistance may be possible, to which they may appear to be entitled.

Rev. Mother Theresine, who is now the Superior General of the Order in France, has spent many years working for the Indian children in the various schools in British Columbia. Rev. Mother Aimee, as Provincial head of the Order, as you are well aware, Mr. Scott, has spent the last thirty years of her life in the service of educating and rearing Indian children at the excellent school maintained by the Sisters at North Vancouver.

The work which has been carried on during that time, is, as you know, invaluable, and I am sure that the Indian Department wishes it to be continued. At the present time the Sisters find it necessary to provide new living quarters for themselves, as the old building is in a state of total dis-repair, and in any event has been far too small for the past few years.

I do hope, dear Mr. Scott, that some assistance will be given these good Sisters, and I am glad to make use of this opportunity to thank you again for all your kind favors of the past, to me in the work of Indian Education in which I took so much interest.

Should this request be given any consideration, I shall as well as these good Sisters, feel deeply grateful for your kind interest.

Most respectfully yours,

Dear Sister Mary Amy:

The Very Reverend Mother Theresine, Superior General of the Sisters of the Child Jesus, visited Ottawa recently and asked that we come to a decision, if possible, concerning a site for the future Squamish Indian Residential School. Of course, I do not know when the Department will be in a position to build a new residential school, but there is no reason why we cannot make an effort to determine what site might be used. I understand that your Order would like to know our wishes before deciding the location for your new Provincial Headquarters. I have today written to Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, asking him to have Mr. Perry make a full report and recommendation in this connection, and I hope to write to you again in the matter in a few weeks.

September 23, 1930.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

The Superior General of the Sisters of the Child Jesus recently visited the Department and discussed the future of the Squamish Indian Residential School. The Order would be very grateful if the Department could indicate what site they would like to use for the continuance of this work. They are not pressing for immediate reconstruction of the school, but they wish to know our plans, so that they can fix a site for their own Provincial Headquarters. Of course, they would like to have the school as near as possible to their Provincial House.

I have to request that you will have Mr. Perry make a full report and recommendation in this connection. On August 28, 1928, he examined a property in the Capilano district and thought it hardly suitable for residential school purposes. At that time, Mr. Perry recommended using the present site and adding to it from the reserve. It occurs to me that the present property might some day come under the control of a harbour commission, as, no doubt, the north shore will some day be required by shipping interests. It has been hinted that even the Squamish Indian Reserve will be needed for industrial purposes in the not distant future. Please have Mr. Perry give this his attention at his convenience. Of course, he should have a full and frank discussion with Sister Mary Amy, Mother Provincial of the Order in British Columbia.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

October 26, 1931.

Dear Mr. Hall:

I wish to refer to your letter of August 14th, last, in connection with local improvements near the vacant property which is used by the Squamish Indian Residential School. The Acting District Resident Architect for the Department of Public Works, who made a report in this matter, states that the property is vacant and has no sewer connections. When Crown property is not connected with a sanitary sewer, it is a matter of grace with the Crown whether a claim is paid to the municipality. The funds at our disposal are so limited, that I regret the Department cannot contribute towards the cost of the recent improvements. You will please so inform the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver.

It may be argued by the Corporation that, in the spring of 1928, the Department committed the local improvement rates for sanitary sewers, permanent grading and pavement in connection with this same block - 123 D. L. 271. It is true that at that time we paid the City of North Vancouver $5,705.30. Funds could be found then for the purpose and consequently the claim was dealt with favourably. The Corporation, when considering our present refusal, should remember that, in the past, we have dealt generously with them.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

Referring to your memorandum of the 16th instant with attached correspondence, I have to say that the lot in question was acquired by His Majesty as represented by the Superintendent General from the Sisters in charge of the Squamish Indian Boarding School, Vancouver, B.C., by instrument dated the 27th day of July, 1922, the consideration being the sum of $2000, plus arrears of taxes and taxes for the current year to the 1st of August amounting in all to the sum of $6919.97. The Sisters were unable to meet the increasing burden of taxes and the lot would eventually have been sold for taxes had not the Department taken the action it did to preserve this lot which was considered necessary for proper conduct of the said school. The fee of this lot having passed to the Crown, the lot ceased to be assessable for taxes by the municipality. It was, however, contended by the municipality that while this was the case, taxes are considered to have been imposed on and from the 1st day of January in each year and that the municipality should accordingly receive taxes in respect of this lot for the full year of 1922. After taking the matter up with the Department of Justice, it was decided to pay the taxes for the remainder of the year, which was done.

In December 1925 the Solicitor of Vancouver wrote the Superintendent General pointing out that upon inquiry he had ascertained that in both Vancouver and Victoria the Dominion
Government had always commuted the local improvements in respect of property held by the Crown and paid the City and the Solicitor at the same time enclosed particulars of local improvements charged against the property in question and asked that the charges for these improvements be commuted. The matter was referred to the Department of Public Works and we were advised by the Acting Deputy Minister that there was no legal obligation, the matter being wholly at the discretion of the Government but that it was not unusual for the Government to pay for local improvements. The improvements in question were subsequently commuted at the sum of $3705.30 and paid, the amount being available from funds voted by Parliament.

The Department is now being asked to commute the payment for sewers recently constructed which commutation amounts to the sum of $965.70. The property in question is vacant and has no sewer connections and we are advised by the Deputy Minister of Public Works that under such circumstances it is a matter of grace with the Crown as to whether this is paid to the municipality. Wing to the fact that our estimates are reduced to a minimum no funds are available for the payment of the requested commutation even if we were favorably disposed towards such payment, and as the municipality has no legal claim for such payment I do not see that it has any real grievance. If it is proposed to pay this claim funds will have to be provided by Parliament.
Ottawa, 14th January, 1932.

Afton, Antigonish Co., N. Scotia March 31, 1904.

His Excellency The Governor General in Council,

The memorial of the undersigned, the Afton and Heatherton Band of Mic-Mac Indians, and also of the white residents ratepayers of the adjoining districts, respectfully showeth:

That the population of the said Indian Band is about 150, and the number of children of school age, that is from 5 to 16 years, is 39.

That these young people are growing up without any schooling, because the Band never had a school of their own, the need of which is felt more and more every year, in view of the progress in that respect made by the white people amongst whom they live.

That your memorialists desire with satisfaction the care and liberality with which the Govt. provide schools for other Bands of Indians in the counties of Halifax, Pictou, on the Island of Cape Breton and elsewhere.

The undersigned earnestly call your attention to the facts of this case, and bespeak your favorable consideration of the situation and circumstances of this Band, and also hope that you will see your way towards providing a school for them at Afton, the most central and populous of the three Indian reserves, and thus placing them on an equal footing with their brethren elsewhere by having the great benefits of education within their reach.

John Stephen, Esq. + Peter Nicholas, Capt. + Frank Tom, Do. + Frank Philip, Do. +

OTTAWA, 25th March, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With further reference to the application for the establishment of an Indian school at Afton I beg to say that I consider that it would be a mistake to grant the prayer of the petitioners for the following reasons:

1. The three small reserves which it is proposed to benefit by opening a school there are so far apart from each other that the same objection of distance would hold good against either locality, while Heatherton, where there is a white school, is between Ponquette and Afton, and Summerside (the other reserve) is only a short distance north of it. The Census gives the population of these reserves as 149. Summerside, containing 100 acres, 32 Indians; Afton, 2 reserves, 160 acres and 245 acres, 78 " Ponquette, 120 acres, 49 ".

The number of school children stated in the petition is correct, about 39.

2. You will see from the foregoing that although the Indians live in separate communities on their reserves, their livelihood is not dependant on the soil. They have to gain their living with or for the whites, and the sooner their children are brought up amongst them and learn the English language the better for their future prospects. As I said
before, there is a white school at Heatherton, which is centrally located and I am sure some suitable arrangement could be made with the Trustees, as is done in other places, for the admission of Indian children.

3. With regard to the prejudice of the Indians against sending their children to white schools, the sooner the Department, the sooner they are helped to overcome this bias the better. That all the Indians are not so prejudiced we will see from Mr Agent McDonald's letter of 16th April 1899, where he recommends the appointment of a young Indian to take charge of a school then proposed who had received his education at the white public school.

4. The only teacher we could get for such a school as is proposed would be an Indian, and our experience of Indian teachers in Nova Scotia has been anything but satisfactory.

5. I consider that the results likely to be obtained from the establishment of such a school would never justify the outlay and if the Indians wish to have their children educated they should have taken advantage of the offer made them some time and sent their children to the white schools.

OTTAWA, 26th April, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In connection with the application of Mr McIsaac, M.P., with further reference to the establishment of a school at Heatherton, N.S., I beg to say that I consider that Father Chisholm's letter to Mr McIsaac only strengthens the hand of the Department in the stand it has taken in this matter. If the Indians are so anxious to have their children educated, their timidity might be overcome.

To His Excellency, The Governor General in Council,

May it please your Excellency,

The memorial of the undersigned, the Chief and Indian Band of Heatherton, Antigonish Co. N.S. and other ratepayers of the surrounding districts, respectfully showeth:

1st. That this Band consists of about 23 families, located on three Reserves, not quite three miles apart, including about 35 school age children, but that this Band never had a school of their own, and they cannot induce their children to attend the school of the whites.

2nd. That in former years, and up to the present time in other localities, the Gov. occasionally distributed blankets one or two to each family, according to the number of members, but that since 25 years no such distribution has been made to this Band.

3rd. That in this Band there are usually, old, sick and dying people, who are absolutely unable to do anything for their own support.

4th. That the Chief in pursuance of his duties as such has to devote a good part of his time to looking after the business of the Band, such as seeing to the necessities of the sick and dying and burials, repairs to the Church etc. etc. whilst at the same time, being a poor man like the rest, the support of himself and family depends on his time and industry.

Therefore the undersigned submit to your favorable consideration the situation of this Indian Band and the facts and circumstances of which can be verified, with a view of obtaining

The Memorial of the undersigned, the chief and heads of families of the Heatherton Band of Indians in the County of Antigonish N.S., and also the ratepayers of the white population of the surrounding districts respectfully showeth:

That there are 40 families in this Band and about 52 children of school age from 5 to 16 years.

That this Band never had a school of their own, although this is the fourth application they have made for such a school within the last 14 years. It is true they were promised $3 a month for each Indian pupil at the school of the whites, but this offer would never do. As a matter of fact and experience the Indian children are too timid to mingle with and compete with white children. Within the specified time not more than 3 Indian pupils could be induced to attend the school of the whites. The result is that the youth continue in the dark to grow up illiterate and it is unnecessary to point out the previous disadvantage under which they suffer in the struggle for subsistence amid an intelligent white population. They feel their grievances the more when they see the Indians of other counties well provided for in the matter of schools.

Your memorialists therefore relying on the facts and merits of their case, and on the favorable consideration thereof by the Minister and the Govt., confidently trust that they will grant with as little delay as practicable the comparatively small setting necessary to provide a school for their children.

Sir,

I beg leave to make the following report on the subject of your letter dated February 22nd last:

I visited two Micmac settlements in Antigonish Co. on the 26th and 27th ultimo, and inquired fully into conditions and circumstances affecting the establishment of a school for the benefit of the Indians in that county. As the Department is aware, there are three settlements, one of which - that at Pompquet or Summerside - need not be taken into consideration in connection with this matter; because its educational requirements are already well provided for by the public school at Heatherton, which is within convenient distance of the Pompquet Indians, whose children - only three in number - attend that school regularly, and that fact narrows the interests remaining to be dealt with to those of the Indians at Heatherton and Bayfield.

These places are rather over than under four miles apart. Bayfield is by far the more important, both in point of population and otherwise. It has 27 children of school age, that is, between 5 and 15 years; while Heatherton has only 10 such children. All parties interested are most anxious for the establishment of a school, and the Heatherton Indians are quite agreed that it should be

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Indian Department,
Ottawa, Ont.
be located at Bayfield for the good of the larger number.

But the fact appears to be that most of the Heatherton Indians intend moving to Bayfield in the near future, as their supply of wood for fuel and for other purposes is exhausted; whereas there is a good supply of wood for all purposes at Bayfield, whose soil also is more fertile, and much of it being intervale, is better adapted for farming operations, than is the case at Heatherton. I think this fact accounts for their willingness to see the school located at Bayfield, and explains their statement to me that they were looking forward to making such arrangements as would enable their children to attend school at Bayfield as soon as one would be established there.

Until I discovered by actual count how many children of school age are at Bayfield, I had no idea the number was so large; otherwise, I would have brought to your notice, on my own initiative, the absolute propriety and necessity of providing school accommodation for their benefit, even should the children at Heatherton not be able to share its advantages; but seeing the attitude of the Heatherton Indians in the matter, I unhesitatingly recommend the establishment of a school at Bayfield with the least possible delay.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Dear Mr. McIsaac:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 31st ultimo, with reference to the position of teacher at the after Indian Day School. I have noted that Mr. Agent Cameron, of Heatherton, is more impressed with Mr. Rogers' success than is our Mr. Boyd.

I am of the opinion that the public school inspector of the Provincial Department of Education is better qualified than either of our officers to inspect a day school and comment on the teacher's success. Mr. A. G. McDonald, Separate School Inspector, of Antigonish, has reported from time to time on Mr. Wm. J. Rogers as follows:

June 1914. "Teacher's success - satisfactory."
May 1916. "The teacher is patient and painstaking and in my opinion is well qualified for the position."
May 1916. "I consider him suitable for the school. He is patient against king and knows considerable about child psychology. The children made good progress."
Nov. 1916. "Teacher's success - satisfactory."
May 1917. "Taking Mr. Rogers' work all in all, I would find it difficult to name a teacher who would do better. He is kind and patient with the children - essential qualities in dealing with his school. The children are fond of him."
May 1918. "He has done well in the school."
April 1919. "Teacher's success - satisfactory."
Dec. 1919. "Teacher's success - satisfactory."
Feb. 1921. "Teacher's success - satisfactory."
June 1922. "On the whole I am satisfied that the management of the school is about as good as one should expect."

In view of Mr. Rogers' long and faithful service, and in the light of the public school inspector's reports from year to year, I am disposed to allow him to continue his work among the Indian children. What is your opinion, now that all the facts have been reviewed?

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the request of Chief Thomas Francis for permission to use the Indian day school building on the Afton Reserve three times each week in order to teach the children their catechism and to hold prayer meetings of the Band.

Regarding this request, please state if there is not a Roman Catholic Church at which these Indians could attend, and who will teach the children their catechism and conduct the prayer meetings on Sunday afternoon. You should also state what arrangement was carried out in the past to provide religious instruction and church services for these Indians, as it is considered that a request of the nature made by the Chief is unusual, and, unless there are sufficient reasons advanced, the Department would not be prepared to authorize the use of the school. When this was done in other places, there were continual complaints as to the condition in which the buildings were left after each service. However, when we have full particulars, we will be in a position to decide whether the Chief's request can be granted or not. Please also state whether the teaching of the catechism and the holding of prayer meetings would be carried on with the approval of the local Parish Priest.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. J. Cameron, Esq.,

Sir,

Replying to your letter No 46-1-1 dated March 20th 1924, the Catholic Church is about three and half miles from the Clifton House, and the Indian Church on the Summerhill Road is about three miles from the Clifton House. In the past the children used to meet in certain hours to be instructed in their catechism. The Chief says that an Indian named Frank Williams is to teach the children and hold the prayer meetings, and this same man very seldom goes to church himself, and I don't think would be capable of teaching the children.

The local Board Point think it would be better if more of the Indians and their children attended school on Sunday. There to have a prayer meeting themselves. I don't think it advisable to give them the school, as they would likely make it a place for the young people to gather and have a good time. I think the custom they had in the past was all right. The children on the Heatherton still do that, gather at a certain one of the houses, and one of the older Indians teaches them their catechism on Sunday afternoon, and the children on the Clifton could do the same if they desire to do so. As Chief Thomas Francis is a new chief he is only trying to start something new. There is no doubt they would leave the school in a dirty condition after those meetings. I would advise the Department not to grant the Chief's request and give them the school.
Sir,

as I am sure the teacher would be complying if the school would not be in the condition he left it. I would therefore recommend that the Department do not give the Chief Authority to get the School. I remain your obedient servant.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the report of the Public School Inspector on the discipline maintained in the classroom by the teacher of the Afton Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say you should instruct Mr. Rogers, the teacher, that he should endeavour to enforce a more strict order of discipline among the pupils during the regular class periods. It is felt that more effective work could be accomplished by him. It is expected that the teacher will use tact in the maintaining of proper order in the classroom. It may be that the attendance will decrease at first; but we believe that, when the Indian children and their parents see that proper order is to be maintained, the pupils will resume a regular attendance.

The Department will approve of the re-engagement of Mr. Rogers for the next school year, beginning September first. Please inform him and arrange with him to resume duties on the date mentioned.

Dear Sir:

On several occasions the following resolution was passed by our committee: "That Mr. Rogers teacher at the Indian school at Afton be dismissed and replaced by Dan MacDonell of Bayfield." Copies of this resolution were forwarded to the committee at Antigonish and also to yourself. We have surmised that our wish was not complied with.

There are several and very good reasons why this change should be effected and we are going to mention some of them.

It is generally known that Mr. Rogers is an aggressive conservative. In the election of Hon. E.M. McDonald he is known to have used rum in an attempt to influence liberal voters. We may add that...
This was mentioned to Hon. Mr. Chisholm last July by one of our committee members.

This school was built in 1912 and Mr. Rogers was teacher since that date. So late he has sent one pupil to high school at Antigonish. This pupil went to Antigonish in the fall of 1924 and was found to stand the grade eight common school work. He is now in grade ten. It is interesting to note that this work is being done in our common schools up to and including grade ten and even grade eleven by the common school teachers of whom Mr. Donald was one.

This student was in Antigonish three years. The government is paying $6 per week for his board in addition to a tuition fee ($50 per year we are told) on a total of $520 a year for work that could and should be done by their teacher at Afton. Of course this may be a boast for Antigonish and perhaps it is one reason why the committee in Antigonish did not take
action. I believe however you will agree with us; that this is an unnecessary expenditure of public money and in itself sufficient cause for dismissal.

We have tried to place the facts of this case fairly before you and if necessary can prove our statements. In conclusion we appeal to you as our representative to remedy this state of affairs which is unfair to the public and still more unfair to your supporters.

Sir,

Without wishing to trespass upon your valuable time, I permit me to ask your consideration of a subject which, I am of urgent necessity, namely, the question of an increase of salary.

The reasons for asking an increase are twofold:

Firstly, the work of teaching the Indians is so difficult, burdensome, and thankless, that it is necessary that the remuneration should be sufficient to provide a reasonable living wage.

Secondly, I wish to render a better and more beneficial service to the Indians and people. If the Department will allow me twelve hundred dollars for the term, I shall be willing to do all I can to aid the adult Indians as well as the pupils and I will spend my vacation doing up some lines of vocational work which I believe is greatly needed on this reserve.
