Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 46-1-1 dated June 26th 1929 regarding the report of the School Inspector of the Afton Indian Day School, I may say that I was always of the opinion that a lady teacher would be better in the Indian School than a man, but when the change was made two years ago, I was not consulted about the appointment made at that time, but I think the present teacher is doing very good. On my recent visit there I found that the children were making fairly good progress and he also teaches them seed work which I think they will find very useful later on in life. The discipline perhaps might be a little better, and I spoke to him about it. He admitted that it was very hard to have the discipline as good in an Indian School as in a white school, and I believe he is right; due to their mode of living, there are naturally more rather than white children, and again when he is teaching them the seed work they get into the habit of being more noisy. On one of my recent visits to the School I took along with me Rev. Father Macdonald who is their spiritual advisor, and he made the remark to me after that he thought they were making very good progress and complimented the teacher on his work in teaching the children and the adults in the seed work they were doing.

Dear Sir:

I resign my position as teacher in the Afton Indian Day School forthwith from January 3rd, 1930.

I am sorry I cannot make an unfavorable recommendation as has been requested by Inspector Woodward's report. Without doubt my position here was not up to the highest standard as you likely knew before you received the written inspector report. However it may not be correct to remark that I do haven't given the time entirely to school work & believe it was not all effort in vain. I have worked about an hour a day and walked nearly everyday; in fact, some people have given me the freedom so that they may permitted to talk and work about. This manual training did not work.
rather of some immediate financial value should also be considered primarily for this purpose.

Cerational training of any kind would I believe be of great use to the Indian pupils. The practice of using the hands to advantage in moulding, weaving, working, etc., is necessary when the pupils are young as without doubt 95 per cent of them a few years later will be trying to earn a living for themselves by the skilled use of their hands even if they should break away from their Indian tribes.

It is interesting to note the work the blind man in Halifax can do towards earning a living. They are trained and have the necessary ambition. The Indians can be trained and probably a desire for work and to mount above the level at which they ordinarily stand could be instilled into their minds through work.

Hope are not naturally lazy or it is not an instinct to be indifferent about work. Environment plays the greatest part in the child's welfare and this is
the biggest obstacle in Indian education. But this can be conquered by gradually having them work in the different lines of livelihood or trades.

And again they are not a stupid people. An example may be noted. A little boy seven years old who started going to school recently without a word of English was looking at the pictures in an atlas' Geography. He noticed a man calling some with a harmonica and "Teacher look" I did so and inquired what the man in the picture was doing. He replied "He taking mean commerce." It is not that they cannot do work that they are below average, but that they are well contented and satisfied with their lot and do not want to advance. An Indian does not worry if he gets a bite to eat at present, supposing there is nothing in view for the future.

I understand you are making very satisfactory progress in your residential schools and no doubt you will continue the work in extending
and encouraging the Indians in every way possible so that before a very long time they may be making a better and more substantial living for themselves as well as setting a good example for their offspring.

I much thank you for assistance given me during my period of service especially in the red line.

With best wishes for the continued advance of Indian civilization.

Yours very truly,

John S. Macdonald.

MEMORANDUM

June 27th, 1935.

Dr. McGill,

Re the position of teacher at the Bayfield Road Indian Day School, your file No. 46-1-1, the Minister has authorized the appointment of Miss Alice McKeough, of Afton Station.

Private Secretary.
Ottawa, June 29, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, enclosing the resignation of Miss Christine Kennedy as teacher of the Afton Indian Day School, to take effect the 30th instant. In reply I have to say that the resignation of Miss Kennedy is accepted, from the date mentioned.

It has been decided to appoint Miss Alice McKeough, of Afton Station, to succeed Miss Kennedy and to begin duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, on September third, next. The salary allowed Miss McKeough will be at the same rate as was paid Miss Kennedy, viz.: $75 per teaching month.

I would request that you inform Miss McKeough of her appointment and arrange that she begins duties on the date mentioned. Please give her any assistance you can in her work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, January 6, 1936.

Dear Mr. Duff:

In the absence of The Honourable the Minister, I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the teacher of the Afton Indian Day School.

Miss Alice McKeough was appointed teacher of this school for the academic year 1935-36, and she began duties on September 1st, last. It has not been the practice of the Department to change teachers in the middle of the academic year unless their services are unsatisfactory. No reports have been received showing that Miss McKeough is not capable of handling this school, and departmental officials feel it would be in the best interests of the children to have her continue in charge of the school until the end of the academic year, viz., June 30th, next.

I have directed the attention of our officials to your recommendation that Mr. Daniel McDonnell, Bayfield, N.S., receive consideration when a teacher is required for this school.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

I have your memorandum of the 14th instant, with attached communication from Mr. William Duff, R. P., recommending the appointment of Daniel McConnell, of Bayfield, as teacher of the Afton Indian Day School for the school year beginning September first, next.

In this connection I would point out that the present teacher, Miss Alice McKeough, who was departmentally appointed, began duties as from September first, 1935. She possesses a Class "C" Nova Scotia Teacher's Certificate. In a recent report from H. M. MacDonald, Provincial Inspector of Schools, on his inspection of this school, he states as follows regarding Miss McKeough's services:

"Miss McKeough, the present teacher, is much above the average teacher. She has lived all her life within five miles of the Indian Reservation and I believe she knows how to deal with these children better than any teacher serving in my district. Her services should be retained as long as possible.

"Miss McKeough is a superior type of teacher and in a few short weeks she has furnished evident indications of progress. The conduct of the pupils is certainly better and the cleanliness and neatness of the children is apparent."

If Miss McKeough's services are terminated - at the Afton
at the Afton School at the end of the present academic year - June 30th, next - would it be in order, in view of her services, to transfer her, should there be a vacancy in another school in Nova Scotia?

The Department has no information concerning the age, qualifications and experience of Daniel McDonnell, whom Mr. Duff has nominated for the position, and I beg to suggest that he be requested to furnish this information.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 20th instant, with attached communication from Rev. H. J. Macdonald, Heatherton, N. S., I feel it inadvisable to reply to him at the present time.

In connection with Miss Alice McKeough's employment as teacher of the Afton Indian Day School, I would refer you to my memorandum of January 22nd, last, and your memorandum of April 30th.

Following the instructions contained in your memorandum, the Indian Agent was written, with a view to obtaining the qualifications possessed by Mr. Daniel MacDonnell, of Heatherton. The Agent replied as follows: "Daniel MacDonnell's home is at Bayfield, but he is not home now. He is employed with some Co-operative Society in South Ingonish, Victoria County, C. B. If the Department wishes me to correspond with him and get this information, please advise me."

The Agent was again instructed, in a letter dated the 8th instant, to communicate at once with Mr. MacDonnell and obtain from him full particulars regarding his qualifications. No reply has yet been received. When the Agent replies, you will be advised.

I am returning herewith the letter of Rev. H. J. Macdonald.

Deputy Superintendent General.

FORM 14
Ottawa, October 6, 1927.

Sir:

I have to request that you will inform Mr. W. J. Rogers, teacher of the Afton Indian Day School, that his services will not be required after November 11th, next. He should prepare and forward, through your office, a return showing the attendance and days taught by him up to the date his services terminate, when the amount of salary due him will be paid.

I have to request that you will immediately communicate with John L. McDonald, Taylor's Road, Antigonish Co., N.S., offering him the position as from November 14th, next. The salary allowed him will be at the same rate as paid Mr. Rogers, viz. $65 per teaching month. You should request Mr. McDonald to state definitely whether he will accept the position as teacher of the Afton School or not, and if he accepts, whether he will be prepared to begin duties on the date mentioned. This matter should receive your immediate attention, and when you have received a reply from Mr. McDonald, you should inform the Department as to whether he accepts the position or not.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aas't. Deputy and Secretary.

W. J. Cameron, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Heatherton, N.S.
Ottawa, October 21st, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, informing the department that Mr. W. J. Rogers will terminate his services as teacher of the Afton Indian Day School on the 11th of November next, also that Mr. John L. McDonald has accepted the position as from November 14th, next.

In reply I beg to say that the Department notes the acceptance of the position at this school by Mr. McDonald and that he will commence duties on the date mentioned.

I am forwarding you a daily register for the use of this school as requested by you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. J. Cameron, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Heatherston, N.S.

Sir,

The Department regrets the illness at this school and hopes that the disease will run the usual course without any fatalities therefrom on the Reserve. The school may remain closed during the illness of the teacher. You might advise Mr. Agent Cameron accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir,

I am enclosing herewith a return for "After Indian Day School" for quarter ending March 31st 1930. You will note the school was closed for some time due to the teacher taking Scarlet Fever, and an epidemic of measles among the school children. This illness the teacher made a great effort in getting away from the school where she was teaching, and it was unfortunate that she took Scarlet Fever after starting teaching. I think she will make a very capable teacher among the Indian children, and that we will be able to keep her.

I do not know what the Department does in a case when the teacher loses some time on account of sickness, but I would recommend if the Department saw proper that they pay her for the full quarter, so that she might remain with the school next term. When she was sick, the children nearly all took the measles, and I am doubtful if she would have had any school were she able to teach.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame building to be used as a school-house on the Indian Reserve at Bayfield, Antigonish County, in the province of Nova Scotia,

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the fifteenth day of October A.D. 1913.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of one thousand eight hundred dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whosoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

The Fine New Indian School at Bayfield and its Neighbor

A Sydney resident who spent the Christmas holidays in the district made remarks on the tremendous increase in the number of Indian residents in that part of the province.

At a point in Aten district adjacent to Bayfield Station, a very fine school has been erected within the last month or two and within easy access of this school a considerable number of Indian dwellings have been built for the accommodation of the largely augmented Indian population.

The school building is a most elaborate and well fitted edifice.

It possesses all the latest, and most convenient, interior fixtures, is well calculated to cope with the ever increasing requirements of the times, and progressive methods of education.

The building is situated on a slight elevation overlooking the immediate neighborhood. The school has two very elaborate verandas, and the entire outline is such as will not allow it to be said that the structure is an eyesore among the beautiful surroundings.

Being entirely for the use of the Indians the building has, of course, been put up by the federal government and is a tribute to the usual thoroughness with which such necessary works are carried out.

In quite contrast to this splendid building is the shabby little hovel which serves as a schoolhouse for the children of the many farmers around. Small, inconveniently situated, and in every way unsuitable and altogether out of keeping with the more recent structures for the provision of education of the Indians.

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Inspector A. F. Chaisson, dated May 12th, 1930, on his inspection of the AFTON Indian Day School.

One Building:

Suggestions Regarding Repairs:

The section of stovepipe leading from the stove nearest the teacher's desk is in poor condition and should be replaced. The lower panels in the front door of school are split and partially torn away and, unless given attention, will not last much longer.

The front steps of the school are broken, the bottom step being supported at present by wire and a few light sticks. I should say that it is unsafe. Three boards ought to be replaced in the entrance platform as they have worn and rotted through. One pane of glass needs to be replaced in the front door and another in a small window next the stockroom. The ceiling of the school-room ought to be whitened. At present, it is very dingy and whitening would result in a much more pleasant room, and presumably a valuable psychological effect on the children's work.

School grounds in good condition. Outside of the points mentioned, the plant is in good condition.

General Remarks: Certain suggestions for improvement have been made under the preceding heading. The teacher would like to have a baseball bat and two softballs for the boys. A swing for the girls would also be well worth while and if it were possible to erect one in the school grounds, I think that it would be an asset. The teacher would like to have 25 tin drinking cups for individual use by the students. At present, they must use the same one or drink out of their hand as I observed some doing. I think that the use of such cups, in addition to promoting sanitation, would also have an educational effect.
Ottawa, May 20, 1930.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Afton Indian Day School, states that the following repairs are required in order to place the school in good condition:

"The section of stovepipe leading from the stove nearest the teacher's desk is in poor condition and should be replaced. The lower panels in the front door of school are split and partially torn away and, unless given attention, will not last much longer. The front steps of the school are broken, the bottom step being supported at present by wire and a few light sticks. I should say that it is unsafe. Three boards ought to be replaced in the entrance platform as they have worn and rotted through. One pane of glass needs to be replaced in the front door and another in a small window next the stockroom. The ceiling of the schoolroom ought to be whitened. At present, it is very dingy. Whitening would result in a much more pleasant room, and presumably a valuable psychological effect on the children's work."

I have to request that you will arrange to have the repairs required as mentioned by the Inspector carried out at the earliest possible date. You should arrange for the purchase of any materials required in the carrying out of the repairs and for the labour. It is expected that you will see no unnecessary expenditure is incurred and that all work is satisfactorily completed. After these repairs have been carried out, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector also recommends that 24 enamel drinking cups be supplied for the individual use of the pupils. You may arrange for the purchase of this number of cups and have them delivered at the school. If hooks are required on which to hang same, you may also make the purchase and have the hooks installed.

The Department is ordering two indoor baseballs and bats, and will forward same to the teacher. One of these outfits is for the use of the boys and the other for the use of the girls.

Sir-

I beg to report that a great part of the school grounds at the Afton Indian Day School is quite grown up with small trees and bushes. As this school is located on the main highway, it would redound very much to the credit of the Department to have these grounds put in proper condition and also greatly improve the appearance of the premises. I understand that in the past these grounds have been cleared but during the last few years they have grown up again. However, I would suggest that another effort be made to improve them and that they be ploughed and seeded this fall.

For this purpose I would recommend that an expenditure of approximately $100.00 be allowed please and in future we shall put a little work on them every year so as to keep them in a proper and attractive condition.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Afton Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the toilets. He states this building is in poor condition and was filthy on the date of his visit. He suggests that locks be placed on the doors and the keys left with the teacher.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the toilets thoroughly cleaned out and placed in a good, sanitary condition. You should also have locks installed on each door and the keys placed in charge of the teacher. The toilets are only to be open during regular school hours.

The Inspector recommends that part of the grounds be plowed in order that the school might organize a garden club next Spring. You might draw this matter to the attention of the Department in the early Spring, giving particulars as to the work to be carried out and the cost of same.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from teacher's report on the Bear River school for the year ending March 31, 1910.

Sickness, sending or taking children begging, going away from Reserve during warm weather, occasionally will keep pupils at home if corrected in school. If the Indians could be induced to remain on the Reserve and cultivate the land so as to have produce for the winter, I think they would be far better off than now. If they were put under some compulsory law in regard to their children attending school, I think would be a benefit to them. Of course, the people are very poor, therefore, in the spring, having no farm implements and no seeds, or fertilizer, or anything needed for farming, they take their families to the seashore. I think if they could be supplied with the above for one or two years, making them understand that from year to year, to try produce their own seeds for future use, as well as what they want to use in their homes, more of them would remain on Reserve, at least, if they would remain until closing of the school for summer vacation.
Ottawa, March 15th, 1910.

Madam,

Referring to your annual report on the Bear River School I beg to say that your remarks with reference to enforcing the compulsory attendance of children have been noted. The Department, however, is not prepared to place the regulations in force on this reserve until all other means have failed.

One of the first essentials is that the teacher should obtain the confidence of the parents. This can only be done by visiting their homes and impressing upon them the necessity of taking advantage of the facilities provided by the Department for the education of their children.

In many of our Indian schools the teachers are giving instruction in sewing and in some cases, where considered advisable, provisions are supplied to give a light mid-day meal. The Department would like to know whether you consider the teaching of sewing would be an incentive to more regular attendance and, if so, whether you would be prepared to take up this work if the necessary materials were provided.

You will be good enough to report fully on the conditions of the homes of these Indians and whether there is any necessity for the provision of a mid-day meal by the Department.

Miss Minnie A. Sheppard,
Teacher,
Bear River, N.S.
Your suggestions in reference to assistance to the parents themselves will be dealt with on another file.

In your report you state that your teacher's certificate is in the Indian Department at Ottawa. Be good enough to state when this certificate was forwarded and to whom, as there is no record of its being received in connection with your appointment to the Bear River School.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa:

I am now writing upon two points in regard to the school on Indian Hill.

The school reopened Sept. 19th instead of the 25th of Aug. I was ready, and half-way on my road to Bear River, when I was informed, that the work on the schoolhouse was not far enough advanced, for me to begin teaching.

The first week was very damp and cold, the stove was not up; I spoke about it and thought it would be up by Friday, so did not go up to the school-house on Thursday, as I had just got over a severe attack of rheumatic neuralgia in my arm and shoulder; that is the reason I did not go to school. Monday morning I was a little late and made up all my time, by giving no recess, teaching part of my dinner-hour and after-school; I always make up any time I lose, on the same day; it does not happen very often.

I am making these explanations for this reason: Mr. Pardee, the Agent, made one of his very few calls, on Monday, and it being the very first time, he did not find me at my post, he made complaints to two parties about me and my time. I was afraid, he did not understand; and as he said, "he had a big report to send in to Ottawa," I thought better for me to
explain my affairs to the Department.

I trust and hope, that the delay in opening the school will not prevent me getting my salary; dear Sir, my circumstances are certainly in a bad condition in regard to finance. I am trying to provide for an income another, so as not to have to send her away and for a sister to take care of her; then having to pay board and other expenses, you see, how I would be situated.

The pictures of His and Her Majesties, King George V and Queen Mary, the Indians are framing and will hang them in the most prominent part of the school-room.

The school-house is all that can be desired; I am just delighted with all parts of it; no fault can be found.

I pay particular attention to the Calisthenics and note an improvement in pupils' shoulders already.

Am I still to continue to give the pupils the mid-day lunch? they are doing well in sewing.

Am I asking too much, when I ask you, if you could please send my cheque direct to myself.

I try to use utmost ability, to do my work faithfully and correctly in every point.

Trusting all the above, will be satisfactory and hoping to be corrected if in any fault,

I remain Yours obediently,

Minnie A. Shea,
Teacher, Indian Ville.

Bear River,

Sir,

The Department considers it advisable to re-commence the serving of a mid-day meal at the Bear River school during the winter months. Miss Shea, the teacher, has submitted to the Department a list of the supplies that she thinks it well to purchase and she estimates that the cost will not exceed $1.50 a week. Sir,

In addition to the general instructions given you in connection with your work as Indian Agent it is desired to add the following respecting schools.

The Department wishes you to pay particular attention to this very important feature. As Indian Agent you are the official who will directly represent the Department and the success of the school in your agency will depend to a large extent upon your cooperation with the teacher. It is noted that where there are capable teachers and enthusiastic agents the Indian schools compare favourably with white schools similarly situated.

You should visit the Bear River school at least monthly. The buildings and surroundings should be kept in good repair. Authority should be obtained before any expenditure is incurred, unless in cases where the sum of money involved is small and delay would cause inconvenience.

All requisitions for school material and supplies and returns of various kinds should be forwarded by the teacher through your office.

You should use your influence with the parents to obtain a regular attendance. A copy of the rules and regulations relating to the education of Indian children is sent you herewith.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR FOSTER ON THE BEAR RIVER DAY SCHOOL.

TEACHER, - Mary Agatha McGinty.

Miss McGinty seems to be doing fair work. There are a few facts however that I wish to report on. In the first place, Miss McGinty seemed to think it was undue interference, on my part in visiting her school. Her manner was "crusty" and by no means pleasing to me.

Her register is not marked daily. I called Friday and there was no attendance marked for the week. She stated she could trust her memory for that period. Again pupils are marked for an entire day, always. There were no half days in Miss McGinty's register nor were the proper marks given for tardiness. I would recommend that Indian teachers certify to the correctness of their register under oath.

School opens at 9.30 and closes at 12 with no recreation period. It opens in the afternoon at 1.30 and closes at 3.30. I would recommend a short recreation period especially in the forenoon session.

Report dated, November 10th, 1916.
Ottawa, November 20th, 1916.

Miss M.A. McGinty,
Teacher
Bear River Day Sch.
Bear River, N.S.

The Department is in receipt of a report on your school by Inspector Foster. He is the authorized inspector of the Bear River school and the Department expects you to extend him every courtesy when he visits the school.

The Inspector states that the register is not correctly marked. If you consult the inside cover of the register supplied by the Department, you will find full explanations as to the manner in which the register should be kept. The register should be marked daily.

Schools Branch -

I think it well to give you some further information in regard to these two teachers.

On the 15th of April, last, Mr. Agent Harris notified the Department that Miss Agatha McGinty had informed him that she would not be able to take this school after the end of the June term.

On the 17th of April of this year Mr. Superintendent Boyd wrote the Department stating that he understood that Miss McGinty, Indian teacher at Bear River School, had resigned her position and, if so, he would recommend that Miss Agnes E. Gorman, an Indian girl from Berwick, who had obtained a Grade "D" Diploma from the Normal School at Truro, N.S., and the cost of whose education and maintenance had been borne by the Department, should be appointed to succeed her. Mr. Agent Harris also recommended Miss Gorman's appointment. The Department informed Mr. Harris that Miss McGinty's resignation would be accepted and that it would approve of the appointment of Miss Gorman, her duties to commence on the re-opening of the school after the summer holidays.

He was also told that the Department had paid for this girl's clothing while she had attended the Normal School, on the understanding that when she began to teach she should refund the money so expended, which amounted to about $90.00. The Department decided, however, to only ask her to refund $75.00. Mr. Harris was informed that if she took charge of the school the sum of $25.00 would be deducted from her her salary each quarter for the first three quarters she teachers to make up this amount.

The great difficulty at this school is to obtain a suitable boarding place for the teacher. Miss McGinty was forced to live in an hotel about a mile and a half from the school. The white family with whom Miss Gorman was living took sick and could not keep her any longer and she was unable to find suitable accommodation, as the white families object to boarding an Indian and she would not live with the Indians on the reserve. The Agent states that the Indians of this reserve are of a very low class and he does not blame Miss Gorman for not wanting to live with them. He also states that Miss Gorman would like to have stayed on until she had paid back what the Department had spent on her, but that it looks as if another teacher will have to be found.

Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from Miss Mary A. McGinty, who is in charge of the Indian school at Bear River, N.S., and who has been its teacher for upwards of six years, with the exception of a break covering a part of the present term, in which she makes a plea for recognition in the matter of bounty allowed by the Department to some Indian teachers for the fiscal year 1918-19, and I have decided to write you in her behalf. I am aware that her claim in that respect is rather defective, according to the terms on which the bounty was granted; but if an exception can possibly be made in any case, I think it should be done in hers for more than one reason.

In my estimation she ranks as one of the most successful, if not the most successful, of our Indian teachers in Nova Scotia, and the fact might well be appreciated in a tangible way. She always gave herself whole-heartedly to her duties, and, as a result, after six years of strenuous and very satisfactory work, her health began to fail. A period of rest was prescribed as necessary in her case, so that it became, one might say, physically impossible for her to retain her position. Therefore, she had to resign her school at the end of the last term, not from choice, but from necessity. After a few months of rest, which restored her to normal health, she applied to be reinstated in her former position whenever the opportunity offered. Under these circumstances, I submit that her plea might be favourably considered by the Department.

The Department is in receipt of the report of the Public School Inspector on his recent inspection of the Bear River Indian Day School. He reports as follows regarding the services of Mr. Wilson H. Ford, who is substituting for his mother, Mrs. Rose Ford:

"I judge that Mr. Ford is doing his best, but nature had not endowed him with teaching gifts. His arrangement of classes was very poor. Although there were only three pupils in Grade III he had this grade split in two classes. The same was true with Grade V.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 12th instant, I have to inform you that the salary rating provided for teachers of Indian day schools in the province of Nova Scotia range from $65 to $80 per teaching month. There is no pension or superannuation provided for teachers. However, a teacher who has given at least 10 years' service receives a gratuity, upon retirement, equal to two months' salary. There is no discrimination in salaries as between male and female teachers.

Madam:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant, enquiring if teachers of Indian schools are subject to the regulations of the Civil Service and eligible for superannuation.

In reply I have to say that teachers in Indian schools are wholly exempt from the operation of the Civil Service Act and are classed as temporary Civil Servants and, as such, do not come under the Superannuation Act for permanent employees of the Federal Government. A teacher of an Indian school, who has had 10 years' continuous employment, would be entitled, upon retirement, to a gratuity equal to two months' salary - this being the only provision made for teachers upon their retirement.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mrs. Ford:

I was surprised and somewhat disturbed to learn from Inspector Foster's last report on your school that there were only 6 pupils in attendance at the time of his visit.

In view of the war conditions in which we now find ourselves, it will be exceedingly difficult to justify the operation of this school unless the attendance can be substantially increased. It is certainly not the intention of the Department to keep Indian day schools open with an average attendance of 6 pupils. If this attendance cannot be substantially increased in the immediate future, an investigation will have to be made to consider the advisability of having these pupils attend either a residential school or the white schools in the neighborhood.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to the Indian Agent. It is my hope that you and the Agent may find it convenient to discuss this matter together and afterwards perhaps with the Indian parents if you consider such action advisable. The Inspector suggests that a letter be sent to Mrs. Levi Brooks, instructing her that her son Andrew must attend school regularly. Mrs. Brooks should be interviewed by you or by the Agent or by both of you and informed that the Department will insist upon the attendance of her boy at school.

I should like to hear from you immediately following your interview with the Agent. I should like to learn also what provision, if any, you have made for vocational instruction at the school - knitting, crochet work, elementary dressmaking, etc.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

I deem it my duty to call your attention to the condition of the school house on the Duncan reserve, Bear River, highly located, which is badly in need of repair. The roof is leaky, especially on one side, and I would advise reshingling with cedar shingles if possible. The main door is without a latch, which should be replaced without delay, as in order to keep the door shut it is necessary to lock it, which is inconvenient. A storm-door also is required and should be provided. Again, the wood shed, attached to the rear of the school house, is in a rather dilapidated condition and requires a new roof; the original covering being almost completely gone. The doors and window casings should be painted; also the doors, and the window-casings, and the walls outside ought to receive a generous coat of whitewash at least.

I am pleased to say that the teacher of the school is giving good satisfaction, circumstances considered; but she is working at a disadvantage for want of common school supplies, which I was surprised to find had not been furnished by the Department. A supply of copy books, drawing books, slates, lead, and dots, pencils, pens, pencil-boxes, and rulers, should, I think, be provided as soon as convenient.

I spoke to the Agent, Mr. Penny about these matters, namely, the condition of the school building, and the absence of text books and supplies absolutely necessary in a school room; and I answered to

CHIMNEY — The old chimney being hung from rafters was found to rest on pieces of 3 X 4 scantling, partly burned through. This was taken down and a new chimney twenty-five feet high was built from the ground; foundation of rock and cement; bricks laid in mortar and cement, and is now thoroughly fire proof. While Mason was at work had all holes in underpinning repaired.

WINDOWS —— The four small windows in building were inadequate to give proper light in School Room. These were taken out and six new windows, two lights in each sash, size of glass 14 X 28, were placed in building, three on either side. All the sashes hung with cords and weights so windows would lower from top and raise from bottom, giving good chance to ventilate room. Beside this, where the old chimney was removed, a galvanized ventilator was placed on roof. (This was advised by Dr. Kendall, who claimed the building would then be perfect as regards ventilation).

ENTRANCE —— A Porch was built, size 8 X 8 ft. — foundation, sills setting on hackmatack posts; sheathed nicely inside, and clapboarded on outside— bottom finished with lattice work; good set of steps, making easy access to building for small pupils. Porch lighted with one two-light window, size of glass 14 X 28.

MAIN BUILDING —— The outside was stripped of shingles and clapboards. On front and two sides these were covered with tarred paper and clapboarded; painted with two coats of white paint. The inside sheathing was hard oiled; platform built across one end of School Room six inches high, on which a desk was built containing three drawers in one side and closet on opposite side to store all books, papers and lunches, etc. A new chair furnished for Teacher; Pupils desks reversed and placed in a position so the small pupils could sit in their seats and use the desks without placing themselves in uncomfortable positions; New Blinds furnished the six new windows; Stove Pipe furnished to connect stove with new chimney.
WOODSHED — This forms a lean-to on the back part of School House and formerly opened in school room. This entrance was closed and door placed in side of shed — one of the old windows placed on opposite side to give light. The side of shed next to School Room was covered with tarred paper and sheathed with lumber, making a suitable place to store wood and kindlings for School purposes.

The inside sheathing was hard oiled; platform built across one end of School Room six inches high, on which a desk was built containing three drawers in one side and closet on opposite side to store all books, papers and lunches, etc. A new chair furnished for Teacher; Pupils desks reversed and placed in a position so the small pupils could sit in their seats and use the desks without placing themselves in uncomfortable positions; New Blinds furnished the six new windows; Stove Pipe furnished to connect stove with new chimney.
WOODSHED — This forms a lean-to on the back part of School House and formerly opened in school room. This entrance was closed and door placed in side of shed — one of the old windows placed on opposite side to give light. The side of shed next to School Room was covered with Tarred Paper and sheathed with lumber, making a suitable place to store wood and kindlings for School purposes.

The Desks are so constructed that for ease and comfort to the pupils, and for strength durability and style they are unsurpassed. The Castings are strong, and the wood is so attached to the iron, as to AVOID THE USE OF SCREWS.

The slats are put together upon the castings by a dove-tail on the iron, and a groove on the slat. The slats are firmly held together by the use of 18 cloves in each slat making the back and seat (although put together on narrow slats in order to get the rake) very firm and the desk very stiff.

The seat closes without noise close against the back, giving a wide passage between the desk for exercises, sweeping, etc., and the desk is easily raised and lowered by means of the lever under the desk. The form of the seat and back renders it perfectly comfortable, the pupil sitting in an erect and healthy position.

The desks are alternately light and dark, and made of seasoned hard wood. The top is provided with a groove, for laying books and papers, and the whole desk is impregnated with oil which prevents the wood from staining in Cherry or Walnut. The whole desk being finished in the best of O.I. Finish which is more durable than ordinary varnish.

In placing the desk in position, care should be used to have the desk out of wind, and perfectly level. There is a flange upon each claw containing three holes; making in all twelve screws which hold the desk firmly to the floor.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 15th ultimo, in which you ask, "is it satisfactory to include the expenditures for several Indians in one letter, providing said expenditures are all clothing, or groceries, or dwelling repairs, as the case may be", I beg to say that a number of recommendations for relief expenditure may be combined in a letter, that is, if they all pertain to the same agency. The same applies to repairs to Indian dwellings. Of course, you understand that relief issues and repairs to Indian dwellings should be dealt with separately. Clothing, as a general rule, is relief. An exception would be clothing purchased for children to allow them to enter the Shubenacadie Residential School; this would be separate and paid for from school vote. Another case would be clothing required for a patient to enter a sanatorium for treatment on account of tuberculosis. This would be paid for from General Vote.

It is difficult to explain these distinctions in a letter, but it is apparent from your accounts and correspondence that you have a good knowledge of the matter.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget,
Chief Accountant.

J.W. Maxner, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

OFFICE OF THE INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT.

RIVER BOURGEOIS, N.S. Nov. 11th, 19—

The Indian teacher at Bear River, N.S., Mrs. Howe, has been ill, and has applied to me for leave to live in her school room during the winter months, and I have informed her by letter of the necessity of submitting the matter to the Department for its decision.

I state what I believe to be a fact, from my knowledge of the place, that she has often of mornings walked road to travel between her dwelling house and her school through deep snow, slush, silt, or drifted, during the night, and yet untiringly, in solitary days for her own, which makes the journey one of much fatigue, and results in her arrival at the scene of her daily labors an object in an exhausted condition, and consequently hardly fit to perform her duties properly.

Although healthy, Mrs. Howe is not strong, being of delicate constitution, and having already experienced much public hardship for one of her age.

Her proposition is to provide herself with a small folding cot which would be able to assure the appearance of an ordinary setting when put in use, and, therefore, would not be an object that might cause dislocation among the pupils during school hours.

She thinks by living in the school room during cold weather that it would always be found warm and comfortable for the children as opposed from their homes, and that she would have an opportunity to prepare and serve their mid-day lunch with better satisfaction both to herself and to them.

C. H. Kellem, Esq.,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs.
OFFICE OF THE INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT.

RIVER BOURGEOIS, N.S.

I have given the matter careful thought, and believe that Mrs. [Name] might be allowed with propriety to live in the school-room during the winter months. I agree with her in the view that her doing so would be of some advantage, and no disadvantage, to the pupils attending her school.

Therefore, I recommend application to the favourable consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir,

As nearly all the teachers on Indian Reserves are provided with a residence and many supplied with fuel, wouldn't it be too much to ask the Dept. to help me settle my rent?

I wouldn't want a house on the Reserve. It would be cruel to ask a teacher to live there when the Village is so near.

I pay Dorly five dollars for my wood and seventy-eight for House - four rooms which takes quite a slice off my salary. Dorly eight is very little to the Dept. but quite an elephant to me.

I am trying to keep my children at school and you, knowing the cost of living can easily see I am up against a difficulty. So be kind and I have gone over my salary every year since came to Bear River.

If you will kindly explain the matter to the Department - which, I ought add, is composed of men & all have hearts, I feel sure they will respond favourably.

For the special reasons mentioned below I hope Your Honour will see the way clear to give the teacher in the Eskerini Indian School an annual salary of three hundred and sixty dollars.

Firstly, of late years wages in every calling except that teaching have gone up at least fifty per cent. With the rise in wages the cost of living has gone up almost proportionately. The wages of teachers in this province, as a rule, not having kept pace with the general increase, a great many of the country schools consequently are closed and there is no prospect of their opening. The Department of Indian Affairs, I believe, will not be the last to give in to the force of circumstances by raising the wages of teachers in their schools if it wants them to be kept open and not be closed like other schools. Besides, more inducements must be offered a white man before he can be got to teach in an Indian school for reasons known to everyone. The teacher who was here last term was a full blooded Indian, and holds in receipt of two hundred and sixty dollars of a salary from the Department of Indian Affairs, yet he found that at the end of the year he had to ship to get out of the way of his creditors who have thus been left in the lurch. The question is, can a white man live cheaper than the Indian and have something to show at the end of the year?

Secondly—Until last year, since time immemorial, the salary of the teacher in the Eskerini Indian School was two hundred dollars. Last year, however, the teacher not having a regular license could not draw a Provincial grant, and the Department, to supply the deficiency added sixty dollars to the two hundred already given—giving him in all two hundred and sixty dollars.
for the School Term. The withholding of the Provincial Grant this year again, but for an entirely different reason, should make the way clear to making a permanent increase in the salary of the teacher here. The Inspector of schools for this district has notified me that though I have a regular license I cannot draw Provincial grant on account of the fact that the section does not comply with all the conditions imposed by the Provincial Government before a grant can be drawn. The principal condition not complied with, is that and which will never be complied with, as far as I can see, is that in order to draw a Provincial Grant the School section must be organized and must be paying taxes out of which the school funds come, but the Indians are not taxed, so their schools cannot participate in the School funds. Now it was formally that the teachers in Indian schools were paid out of the County and Provincial funds, I find it hard to understand unless someone overlooked certainness of the law or perhaps late legislation did it.

There are many schools vacant in this Province, and I could easily get one paying even better than this Indian school, but I was asked, after failing to procure a teacher at the rate of two hundred and sixty dollars a term and Provincial grant besides—thinking the section would draw Provincial grant—by a friend who has the interests of the Indians much at heart, and who wanted to see their school open, knowing that of any class of people the uneducated Indian is the worst off when he goes out into the world. The Chief of the Micmac Indians of the Maritime Provinces lives here and is doing his best for the education of his subjects. By settling the various disputes all over the Maritime Provinces he saves
much trouble to the Department of Indian Affairs. The former white teacher in this school had a house and farm within easy reach of the school house and so could afford to teach for less. I have to pay my board and that in a place about two miles from the school house for it would be impossible to teach here in an Indian house. All which involves extra trouble and work.

The Department will, I hope, see its way clear to grant the reasonable salary of three hundred and sixty dollars. The Indian Agent here and the Inspector of public schools think it right that an increase should be made.

I am,

Your obedient servant,
Patrick Beaton.

P.S. Please send me a form for quarterly school return, and if the increase of salary is granted a manual of school law.

Dear Sir:

I enclose the letter of the Chief in re the engagement of Mr. Bernard as teacher for the Eskaton reserve this year. I had nothing to do with affair; in fact I told Mr. Bernard when he spoke to me before he was engaged about the school that I would neither recommend his appointment to your Department nor sanction it in any way. My reason was as I told him, the flight in which he left all his creditors when he left the section before. I had no fault to find with him as teacher. Perhaps on account of his knowledge of his mother tongue, he was better able to connect to the very young who were too tall ignorant of English, the rudiments of education than a white teacher could be.

The Chief who is unable to write and who has a large congregation to attend to on account of his being Grand Chief of the whole province found Mr. Bernard very useful as his secretary. Hence I believe his anxiety to have him engaged as teacher. I think it would be well for your Department to plainly tell the chief the limits of his jurisdiction in matters like this. I have nothing but praise for the Chief. He does all he can for the good of the tribe. His word is law to them. But he should be told that he cannot ignore your Department in a case like this.

I remain,

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Sup't. General.

On the 26th August last a letter addressed to the Rev. Mr. Cameron by Grand Chief John Denny of Eskasoni, was received in the Department without any covering letter. Chief Denny recommended the appointment of Mr. Chas. Bernard as teacher of the Indian School on that Reserve. As no intimation had been received of the intention of Mr. Boyle, who was in charge of the school, to resign, Mr. Cameron was informed that if Mr. Boyle decided to resign, the question of appointing his successor would be considered then. On the 26th September last Chief Denny wrote the Department stating that he had appointed Mr. Bernard as teacher of this school, and Mr. Agent Cameron also enclosed a letter addressed to him by the Chief also advising him of his having appointed Mr. Bernard. The Chief had no authority to appoint Bernard or to ask for the resignation of Mr. Boyle, and Mr. Cameron took the proper course when he closed the school to await the Department's instructions with regard to Bernard's appointment.

Mr. Cameron says he had nothing to do with this appointment; and in fact he told Mr. Bernard when he spoke to him about the school that he would neither recommend his appointment to the Department nor sanction it in any way, on account of the unsatisfactory manner he had dealt with his creditors when he was formerly employed at Eskasoni as teacher. Bernard was dismissed from this position of teacher of the Burnt Church School at the end of June quarter last by your direction. The Agent says that Bernard makes himself useful to the Chief, who has great influence over the Indians, but is unable to write and finds Bernard's services as secretary very useful. He also says that he had no fault to find with.
with Bernard as a teacher; but Bernard proved himself to very

The Chief was not home that day, but I told his son my errand and to tell his father to write me when he could come home from St. Peters. Sir,

A friend, who had the interest of the Indian school at Eskasoni at heart, has asked me to teach here for some time, as the Chief had failed to get a teacher to keep the school open. I am willing to give a chance to the Indians growing up to acquire elementary knowledge, and especially to prevent them from falling into the bad habit of staying away from school, which they certainly would acquire if the school was closed for any length of time.

This friend of mine and the Chief wrote me asking me if possible to go to teach here for some time—and if the salary was low to make an application for a decent living salary, to the Department of Indian Affairs. This Indian school is quite different from the other Indian schools in Cape Breton and other Counties, in so much as it does not draw any Provincial or County Grant, by it is said to not have.

The salary paid by the Dominion Government is three hundred dollars a year, and that is all the income a teacher has who teaches here.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr. John F. Beaton, teacher of the Eskasoni school, has applied for an increase of salary. He is at present in receipt of $300 per year, and although he makes out a good case I do not see how the Department can pay him more without making an all-round increase.

Mr. Beaton is mistaken in his statement that the teacher of the Sydney school is in receipt of $500 per annum. The Department only pays that school $300 now, although for one year it paid Miss Connolly $300 as teacher and $100 as field matron, but after her resignation the field matron salary was dropped.

None of the Indian school teachers receive any of the Nova Scotia provincial grant; this was withdrawn about two years ago, and we have time and again explained to the agents and teachers that this Department has no connection with the provincial school system and that we have no claim on them for any grant. The engagement of the teacher is made with this Department and they know what they are going to receive when they accept the position and have no claim for any more. Of course the present salary is low, and unless, as I said before, a general increase is made, I do not see how an exception can be made in Mr. Beaton's favour.

Dear Sirs,

I hope you will not deem it inexpedient for me to ask you for some increase in the salary paid to the teachers of the Indian government school at Eskasoni, Cape Breton Co.

If the school were situated where one could obtain board within a quarter of a mile, there would not be such need for complaints; but when one has to walk a distance of three and a half miles every morning and evening to the nearest hotel house making a distance of seven miles to walk, there is sufficient cause.

Again you have to force yourself on the nearest house, and prevail on them to take you against their will.
and as a result you must be content to pay a board bill at whatever price is asked.

Again one could get along all right in the summer months but during the fall and winter, you must be up before daylight to reach school at the required hour, and also the school is pretty old and cold to spend the winter hours in.

Besides in this school, the teacher does not get one cent of provincial grant over his salary. This is new to a second class teacher, if he teaches the full two days amounts to $120 in this province. That taken off this school's salary would only leave $180 a salary which the poorest school section in the province can boast over. If the salary could be raised to $40, then I should consider that it would satisfy for the hardships which one has to undergo.

I appeal to you once more to think this matter over and give it some consideration.
When I took this school it was under the consideration that I could draw a First Class provincial grant besides my salary from you, but since there proved out that no provincial grant is paid to teachers' salaries, find that one has to be content with the meagre salary that is paid by the Department. So hoping you will increase the salary to $400, and trusting to hear from you soon.

The Deputy Supt. General:-

Mr. D.D. McKenzie, M.P., Cape Breton, incloses a letter from Mrs. Roderick McMillan, widow of a former teacher of the Indian school at Eskasoni, applying for a pension.

She is under the impression that the Department makes provision for the widows of teachers of Indian schools after twenty years' service. I may say that there is no such provision made and the most the Department has ever done for teachers who have been a long time in its service has been to grant them a lump sum as a bonus on retirement.

Mr. McMillan taught for twenty-one years continuously with fair success and, had he applied for a bonus at the time of his retirement in 1900, it would most likely have been considered favourably. He did not do so and no grant was made.

It is for the Department to say whether after the lapse of time since his retirement it would be willing to make a grant to his widow in recognition of his services. If it felt disposed to do so, $150.00 would be about the amount she might be given on the basis of the grants already made to other teachers who have received bonuses on retirement.

Martin Benson

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. J. J. McKinnon, Indian Agent, in which he speaks in very high terms of the work being performed by you in the Eskasoni school.

There is, however, one regrettable feature; that is the irregular attendance. The Department is very anxious that these Indians should take advantage of the facilities provided to educate their children and trusts that you will use your influence with the parents. The experience of the Department has shown that very much depends upon the personality of the teacher. If he succeeds in obtaining the confidence of the parents, the greatest obstacle to good attendance is overcome. The Department would be glad, therefore, if you would visit in the homes of the Indians and make an effort to induce them to send their children regularly, pointing out the advantages that will accrue to them and using any other means you may consider advisable.

Trusting that a later report will show a decided improvement,

Your obedient Servant,
